<table border="0"><tbody><tr><td class="ind" indent="1"><img src="s.gif" height="1" width="40"></td><td valign="top" class="votelinks"><center><a id="up_44828647" href="vote?id=44828647&amp;how=up&amp;goto=item%3Fid%3D44826997"><div class="votearrow" title="upvote"></div></a></center></td><td class="default"><div style="margin-top:2px; margin-bottom:-10px;"><span class="comhead"><a href="user?id=strongpigeon" class="hnuser">strongpigeon</a> <span class="age" title="2025-08-07T18:40:02 1754592002"><a href="item?id=44828647">38 minutes ago</a></span> <span id="unv_44828647"></span><span class="navs">| <a href="#44828137" class="clicky" aria-hidden="true">parent</a> | <a href="#44828930" class="clicky" aria-hidden="true">prev</a> | <a href="#44828343" class="clicky" aria-hidden="true">next</a> <a class="togg clicky" id="44828647" n="1" href="javascript:void(0)">[–]</a><span class="onstory"></span></span></span></div><br><div class="comment"><div class="commtext c00">I think this is because of an expectation of a snowball effect once a model becomes able to improve itself. See talks about the Singularity.<p>I personally think it's a pretty reductive model for what intelligence is, but a lot of people seem to strongly believe in it.</p></div><div class="reply"><p><font size="1"><u><a href="reply?id=44828647&amp;goto=item%3Fid%3D44826997%2344828647" rel="nofollow">reply</a></u></font></p></div></div></td></tr></tbody></table>

<table border="0"><tbody><tr><td class="ind" indent="1"><img src="s.gif" height="1" width="40"></td><td valign="top" class="votelinks"><center><a id="up_44828343" href="vote?id=44828343&amp;how=up&amp;goto=item%3Fid%3D44826997"><div class="votearrow" title="upvote"></div></a></center></td><td class="default"><div style="margin-top:2px; margin-bottom:-10px;"><span class="comhead"><a href="user?id=porphyra" class="hnuser">porphyra</a> <span class="age" title="2025-08-07T18:18:31 1754590711"><a href="item?id=44828343">1 hour ago</a></span> <span id="unv_44828343"></span><span class="navs">| <a href="#44828137" class="clicky" aria-hidden="true">parent</a> | <a href="#44828647" class="clicky" aria-hidden="true">prev</a> | <a href="#44829041" class="clicky" aria-hidden="true">next</a> <a class="togg clicky" id="44828343" n="1" href="javascript:void(0)">[–]</a><span class="onstory"></span></span></span></div><br><div class="comment"><div class="commtext c00">It seems that the new tricks that people discover to slightly improve the model, be it a new reinforcement learning technique or whatever, get leaked/shared quickly to other companies and there really isn't a big moat. I would have thought that whoever is rich enough to afford tons of compute first would start pulling away from the rest but so far that doesn't seem to be the case --- even smaller players without as much compute are staying in the race.</div><div class="reply"><p><font size="1"><u><a href="reply?id=44828343&amp;goto=item%3Fid%3D44826997%2344828343" rel="nofollow">reply</a></u></font></p></div></div></td></tr></tbody></table>

<table border="0"><tbody><tr><td class="ind" indent="1"><img src="s.gif" height="1" width="40"></td><td valign="top" class="votelinks"><center><a id="up_44829041" href="vote?id=44829041&amp;how=up&amp;goto=item%3Fid%3D44826997"><div class="votearrow" title="upvote"></div></a></center></td><td class="default"><div style="margin-top:2px; margin-bottom:-10px;"><span class="comhead"><a href="user?id=klik99" class="hnuser">klik99</a> <span class="age" title="2025-08-07T19:12:06 1754593926"><a href="item?id=44829041">6 minutes ago</a></span> <span id="unv_44829041"></span><span class="navs">| <a href="#44828137" class="clicky" aria-hidden="true">parent</a> | <a href="#44828343" class="clicky" aria-hidden="true">prev</a> | <a href="#44828779" class="clicky" aria-hidden="true">next</a> <a class="togg clicky" id="44829041" n="1" href="javascript:void(0)">[–]</a><span class="onstory"></span></span></span></div><br><div class="comment"><div class="commtext c00">I’ve been saying for a while if AGI is possible it’s going to take another innovation and the transformer / LLM paradigm will plateau, and innovations are hard to time. I used to get downvoted for saying that years ago and now more people are realizing it. LLMs are awesome but there is a limit, most of the interesting things in the next years will be bolting more functionality and agent stuff, introspection like Anthropic is working on and smaller, less compute hungry specialized models. There’s still a lot to explore in this paradigm, but we’re getting diminishing returns on newer models, especially when you factor in cost</div><div class="reply"><p><font size="1"><u><a href="reply?id=44829041&amp;goto=item%3Fid%3D44826997%2344829041" rel="nofollow">reply</a></u></font></p></div></div></td></tr></tbody></table>

<table border="0"><tbody><tr><td class="ind" indent="1"><img src="s.gif" height="1" width="40"></td><td valign="top" class="votelinks"><center><a id="up_44828779" href="vote?id=44828779&amp;how=up&amp;goto=item%3Fid%3D44826997"><div class="votearrow" title="upvote"></div></a></center></td><td class="default"><div style="margin-top:2px; margin-bottom:-10px;"><span class="comhead"><a href="user?id=citizenpaul" class="hnuser">citizenpaul</a> <span class="age" title="2025-08-07T18:50:15 1754592615"><a href="item?id=44828779">28 minutes ago</a></span> <span id="unv_44828779"></span><span class="navs">| <a href="#44828137" class="clicky" aria-hidden="true">parent</a> | <a href="#44829041" class="clicky" aria-hidden="true">prev</a> | <a href="#44828508" class="clicky" aria-hidden="true">next</a> <a class="togg clicky" id="44828779" n="1" href="javascript:void(0)">[–]</a><span class="onstory"></span></span></span></div><br><div class="comment"><div class="commtext c00">Even at the beginning of the year people were still going crazy over new model releases. Now the various model update pages are starting to average times in the months since their last update rather than days/weeks. This is across the board. Not limited to a single model.</div><div class="reply"><p><font size="1"><u><a href="reply?id=44828779&amp;goto=item%3Fid%3D44826997%2344828779" rel="nofollow">reply</a></u></font></p></div></div></td></tr></tbody></table>

<table border="0"><tbody><tr><td class="ind" indent="1"><img src="s.gif" height="1" width="40"></td><td valign="top" class="votelinks"><center><a id="up_44828508" href="vote?id=44828508&amp;how=up&amp;goto=item%3Fid%3D44826997"><div class="votearrow" title="upvote"></div></a></center></td><td class="default"><div style="margin-top:2px; margin-bottom:-10px;"><span class="comhead"><a href="user?id=bmau5" class="hnuser">bmau5</a> <span class="age" title="2025-08-07T18:30:31 1754591431"><a href="item?id=44828508">48 minutes ago</a></span> <span id="unv_44828508"></span><span class="navs">| <a href="#44828137" class="clicky" aria-hidden="true">parent</a> | <a href="#44828779" class="clicky" aria-hidden="true">prev</a> | <a href="#44828706" class="clicky" aria-hidden="true">next</a> <a class="togg clicky" id="44828508" n="1" href="javascript:void(0)">[–]</a><span class="onstory"></span></span></span></div><br><div class="comment"><div class="commtext c00">The idea is that with AGI it will then be able to self improve orders of magnitude faster than it would if relying on humans for making the advances. It tracks that the improvements are all relatively similar at this point since they're all human-reliant.</div><div class="reply"><p><font size="1"><u><a href="reply?id=44828508&amp;goto=item%3Fid%3D44826997%2344828508" rel="nofollow">reply</a></u></font></p></div></div></td></tr></tbody></table>

<table border="0"><tbody><tr><td class="ind" indent="1"><img src="s.gif" height="1" width="40"></td><td valign="top" class="votelinks"><center><a id="up_44828706" href="vote?id=44828706&amp;how=up&amp;goto=item%3Fid%3D44826997"><div class="votearrow" title="upvote"></div></a></center></td><td class="default"><div style="margin-top:2px; margin-bottom:-10px;"><span class="comhead"><a href="user?id=fdsjgfklsfd" class="hnuser">fdsjgfklsfd</a> <span class="age" title="2025-08-07T18:44:32 1754592272"><a href="item?id=44828706">34 minutes ago</a></span> <span id="unv_44828706"></span><span class="navs">| <a href="#44828137" class="clicky" aria-hidden="true">parent</a> | <a href="#44828508" class="clicky" aria-hidden="true">prev</a> | <a href="#44828731" class="clicky" aria-hidden="true">next</a> <a class="togg clicky" id="44828706" n="2" href="javascript:void(0)">[–]</a><span class="onstory"></span></span></span></div><br><div class="comment"><div class="commtext c00">I think they're just reaching the limits of this architecture and when a new type is invented it will be a much bigger step.</div><div class="reply"><p><font size="1"><u><a href="reply?id=44828706&amp;goto=item%3Fid%3D44826997%2344828706" rel="nofollow">reply</a></u></font></p></div></div></td></tr></tbody></table>

<table border="0"><tbody><tr><td class="ind" indent="2"><img src="s.gif" height="1" width="80"></td><td valign="top" class="votelinks"><center><a id="up_44828764" href="vote?id=44828764&amp;how=up&amp;goto=item%3Fid%3D44826997"><div class="votearrow" title="upvote"></div></a></center></td><td class="default"><div style="margin-top:2px; margin-bottom:-10px;"><span class="comhead"><a href="user?id=hodgehog11" class="hnuser">hodgehog11</a> <span class="age" title="2025-08-07T18:49:30 1754592570"><a href="item?id=44828764">29 minutes ago</a></span> <span id="unv_44828764"></span><span class="navs">| <a href="#44828137" class="clicky" aria-hidden="true">root</a> | <a href="#44828706" class="clicky" aria-hidden="true">parent</a> | <a href="#44828731" class="clicky" aria-hidden="true">next</a> <a class="togg clicky" id="44828764" n="1" href="javascript:void(0)">[–]</a><span class="onstory"></span></span></span></div><br><div class="comment"><div class="commtext c00">Working in the theory, I can say this is incredibly unlikely. At scale, once appropriately trained, all architectures begin to converge in performance.<p>It's not architectures that matter anymore, it's unlocking new objectives and modalities that open another axis to scale on.</p></div><div class="reply"><p><font size="1"><u><a href="reply?id=44828764&amp;goto=item%3Fid%3D44826997%2344828764" rel="nofollow">reply</a></u></font></p></div></div></td></tr></tbody></table>

<table border="0"><tbody><tr><td class="ind" indent="1"><img src="s.gif" height="1" width="40"></td><td valign="top" class="votelinks"><center><a id="up_44828731" href="vote?id=44828731&amp;how=up&amp;goto=item%3Fid%3D44826997"><div class="votearrow" title="upvote"></div></a></center></td><td class="default"><div style="margin-top:2px; margin-bottom:-10px;"><span class="comhead"><a href="user?id=hodgehog11" class="hnuser">hodgehog11</a> <span class="age" title="2025-08-07T18:46:31 1754592391"><a href="item?id=44828731">32 minutes ago</a></span> <span id="unv_44828731"></span><span class="navs">| <a href="#44828137" class="clicky" aria-hidden="true">parent</a> | <a href="#44828706" class="clicky" aria-hidden="true">prev</a> | <a href="#44828776" class="clicky" aria-hidden="true">next</a> <a class="togg clicky" id="44828731" n="1" href="javascript:void(0)">[–]</a><span class="onstory"></span></span></span></div><br><div class="comment"><div class="commtext c5A">It's still not necessarily wrong, just unlikely. Once these developers start using the model to update itself, beyond an unknown threshold of capability, one model could start to skyrocket in performance above the rest. We're not in that phase yet, but judging from what the devs at the end were saying, we're getting uncomfortably (and irresponsibly) close.</div><div class="reply"><p><font size="1"><u><a href="reply?id=44828731&amp;goto=item%3Fid%3D44826997%2344828731" rel="nofollow">reply</a></u></font></p></div></div></td></tr></tbody></table>

<table border="0"><tbody><tr><td class="ind" indent="1"><img src="s.gif" height="1" width="40"></td><td valign="top" class="votelinks"><center><a id="up_44828776" href="vote?id=44828776&amp;how=up&amp;goto=item%3Fid%3D44826997"><div class="votearrow" title="upvote"></div></a></center></td><td class="default"><div style="margin-top:2px; margin-bottom:-10px;"><span class="comhead"><a href="user?id=logicchains" class="hnuser">logicchains</a> <span class="age" title="2025-08-07T18:50:09 1754592609"><a href="item?id=44828776">28 minutes ago</a></span> <span id="unv_44828776"></span><span class="navs">| <a href="#44828137" class="clicky" aria-hidden="true">parent</a> | <a href="#44828731" class="clicky" aria-hidden="true">prev</a> | <a href="#44828749" class="clicky" aria-hidden="true">next</a> <a class="togg clicky" id="44828776" n="1" href="javascript:void(0)">[–]</a><span class="onstory"></span></span></span></div><br><div class="comment"><div class="commtext c00">&gt;It's interesting to note that at least so far, the trend has been the opposite: as time goes on and the models get better, the performance of the different company's gets clustered closer together<p>It's natural if you extrapolate from training loss curves; a training process with continually diminishing returns to more training/data is generally not something that suddenly starts producing exponentially bigger improvements.</p></div><div class="reply"><p><font size="1"><u><a href="reply?id=44828776&amp;goto=item%3Fid%3D44826997%2344828776" rel="nofollow">reply</a></u></font></p></div></div></td></tr></tbody></table>

<table border="0"><tbody><tr><td class="ind" indent="1"><img src="s.gif" height="1" width="40"></td><td valign="top" class="votelinks"><center><a id="up_44828749" href="vote?id=44828749&amp;how=up&amp;goto=item%3Fid%3D44826997"><div class="votearrow" title="upvote"></div></a></center></td><td class="default"><div style="margin-top:2px; margin-bottom:-10px;"><span class="comhead"><a href="user?id=koonsolo" class="hnuser">koonsolo</a> <span class="age" title="2025-08-07T18:48:28 1754592508"><a href="item?id=44828749">30 minutes ago</a></span> <span id="unv_44828749"></span><span class="navs">| <a href="#44828137" class="clicky" aria-hidden="true">parent</a> | <a href="#44828776" class="clicky" aria-hidden="true">prev</a> | <a href="#44828691" class="clicky" aria-hidden="true">next</a> <a class="togg clicky" id="44828749" n="2" href="javascript:void(0)">[–]</a><span class="onstory"></span></span></span></div><br><div class="comment"><div class="commtext c00">This confirms my suspicion that we are not at the exponential part of the curve, but the flattening one. It's easier to stay close to your competitors when everyone is at the flat curve of the innovation.<p>The improvements they make are marginal. How long until the next AI breakthrough? Who can tell? Because last time it took decenia.</p></div><div class="reply"><p><font size="1"><u><a href="reply?id=44828749&amp;goto=item%3Fid%3D44826997%2344828749" rel="nofollow">reply</a></u></font></p></div></div></td></tr></tbody></table>

<table border="0"><tbody><tr><td class="ind" indent="2"><img src="s.gif" height="1" width="80"></td><td valign="top" class="votelinks"><center><a id="up_44829044" href="vote?id=44829044&amp;how=up&amp;goto=item%3Fid%3D44826997"><div class="votearrow" title="upvote"></div></a></center></td><td class="default"><div style="margin-top:2px; margin-bottom:-10px;"><span class="comhead"><a href="user?id=chasd00" class="hnuser">chasd00</a> <span class="age" title="2025-08-07T19:12:25 1754593945"><a href="item?id=44829044">6 minutes ago</a></span> <span id="unv_44829044"></span><span class="navs">| <a href="#44828137" class="clicky" aria-hidden="true">root</a> | <a href="#44828749" class="clicky" aria-hidden="true">parent</a> | <a href="#44828691" class="clicky" aria-hidden="true">next</a> <a class="togg clicky" id="44829044" n="1" href="javascript:void(0)">[–]</a><span class="onstory"></span></span></span></div><br><div class="comment"><div class="commtext c00">I think the breakthroughs now will be the application of LLMs to the rest of the world. Discovering use cases where LLMs really shine and applying them while learning and sharing the use cases where they do not.</div><div class="reply"><p><font size="1"><u><a href="reply?id=44829044&amp;goto=item%3Fid%3D44826997%2344829044" rel="nofollow">reply</a></u></font></p></div></div></td></tr></tbody></table>

<table border="0"><tbody><tr><td class="ind" indent="1"><img src="s.gif" height="1" width="40"></td><td valign="top" class="votelinks"><center><a id="up_44828691" href="vote?id=44828691&amp;how=up&amp;goto=item%3Fid%3D44826997"><div class="votearrow" title="upvote"></div></a></center></td><td class="default"><div style="margin-top:2px; margin-bottom:-10px;"><span class="comhead"><a href="user?id=babypuncher" class="hnuser">babypuncher</a> <span class="age" title="2025-08-07T18:43:02 1754592182"><a href="item?id=44828691">35 minutes ago</a></span> <span id="unv_44828691"></span><span class="navs">| <a href="#44828137" class="clicky" aria-hidden="true">parent</a> | <a href="#44828749" class="clicky" aria-hidden="true">prev</a> | <a href="#44828650" class="clicky" aria-hidden="true">next</a> <a class="togg clicky" id="44828691" n="1" href="javascript:void(0)">[–]</a><span class="onstory"></span></span></span></div><br><div class="comment"><div class="commtext c00">I would argue that this is because we are reaching the practical limits of this technology and AGI isn't nearly as close as people thought.</div><div class="reply"><p><font size="1"><u><a href="reply?id=44828691&amp;goto=item%3Fid%3D44826997%2344828691" rel="nofollow">reply</a></u></font></p></div></div></td></tr></tbody></table>

<table border="0"><tbody><tr><td class="ind" indent="1"><img src="s.gif" height="1" width="40"></td><td valign="top" class="votelinks"><center><a id="up_44828650" href="vote?id=44828650&amp;how=up&amp;goto=item%3Fid%3D44826997"><div class="votearrow" title="upvote"></div></a></center></td><td class="default"><div style="margin-top:2px; margin-bottom:-10px;"><span class="comhead"><a href="user?id=belter" class="hnuser">belter</a> <span class="age" title="2025-08-07T18:40:11 1754592011"><a href="item?id=44828650">38 minutes ago</a></span> <span id="unv_44828650"></span><span class="navs">| <a href="#44828137" class="clicky" aria-hidden="true">parent</a> | <a href="#44828691" class="clicky" aria-hidden="true">prev</a> | <a href="#44828553" class="clicky" aria-hidden="true">next</a> <a class="togg clicky" id="44828650" n="1" href="javascript:void(0)">[–]</a><span class="onstory"></span></span></span></div><br><div class="comment"><div class="commtext c00">Nobody seems to be on the path to AGI as long as the model of today is as good as the model of tomorrow. And as long as there are "releases". You don't release a new human every few months...LLMs are currently frozen sequence predictors whose static weights stop learning after training.<p>They lack writable long-term memory beyond a context window. They operate without any grounded perception-action loop to test hypotheses. And they possess no executive layer for goal directed planning or self reflection...</p><p>Achieving AGI demands continuous online learning with consolidation.</p></div><div class="reply"><p><font size="1"><u><a href="reply?id=44828650&amp;goto=item%3Fid%3D44826997%2344828650" rel="nofollow">reply</a></u></font></p></div></div></td></tr></tbody></table>

<table border="0"><tbody><tr><td class="ind" indent="1"><img src="s.gif" height="1" width="40"></td><td valign="top" class="votelinks"><center><a id="up_44828553" href="vote?id=44828553&amp;how=up&amp;goto=item%3Fid%3D44826997"><div class="votearrow" title="upvote"></div></a></center></td><td class="default"><div style="margin-top:2px; margin-bottom:-10px;"><span class="comhead"><a href="user?id=dvfjsdhgfv" class="hnuser">dvfjsdhgfv</a> <span class="age" title="2025-08-07T18:33:34 1754591614"><a href="item?id=44828553">45 minutes ago</a></span> <span id="unv_44828553"></span><span class="navs">| <a href="#44828137" class="clicky" aria-hidden="true">parent</a> | <a href="#44828650" class="clicky" aria-hidden="true">prev</a> | <a href="#44828686" class="clicky" aria-hidden="true">next</a> <a class="togg clicky" id="44828553" n="1" href="javascript:void(0)">[–]</a><span class="onstory"></span></span></span></div><br><div class="comment"><div class="commtext c00">&gt; It's frequently suggested that once one of the AI companies reaches an AGI threshold, they will take off ahead of the rest.<p>This argument has so many weak points it deserves a separate article.</p></div><div class="reply"><p><font size="1"><u><a href="reply?id=44828553&amp;goto=item%3Fid%3D44826997%2344828553" rel="nofollow">reply</a></u></font></p></div></div></td></tr></tbody></table>

<table border="0"><tbody><tr><td class="ind" indent="1"><img src="s.gif" height="1" width="40"></td><td valign="top" class="votelinks"><center><a id="up_44828686" href="vote?id=44828686&amp;how=up&amp;goto=item%3Fid%3D44826997"><div class="votearrow" title="upvote"></div></a></center></td><td class="default"><div style="margin-top:2px; margin-bottom:-10px;"><span class="comhead"><a href="user?id=shortrounddev2" class="hnuser">shortrounddev2</a> <span class="age" title="2025-08-07T18:42:45 1754592165"><a href="item?id=44828686">35 minutes ago</a></span> <span id="unv_44828686"></span><span class="navs">| <a href="#44828137" class="clicky" aria-hidden="true">parent</a> | <a href="#44828553" class="clicky" aria-hidden="true">prev</a> | <a href="#44828661" class="clicky" aria-hidden="true">next</a> <a class="togg clicky" id="44828686" n="1" href="javascript:void(0)">[–]</a><span class="onstory"></span></span></span></div><br><div class="comment"><div class="commtext c00">Maybe because they haven't created an engine for AGI, but a really really impressive bullshit generator.</div><div class="reply"><p><font size="1"><u><a href="reply?id=44828686&amp;goto=item%3Fid%3D44826997%2344828686" rel="nofollow">reply</a></u></font></p></div></div></td></tr></tbody></table>

<table border="0"><tbody><tr><td class="ind" indent="0"><img src="s.gif" height="1" width="0"></td><td valign="top" class="votelinks"><center><a id="up_44828661" href="vote?id=44828661&amp;how=up&amp;goto=item%3Fid%3D44826997"><div class="votearrow" title="upvote"></div></a></center></td><td class="default"><div style="margin-top:2px; margin-bottom:-10px;"><span class="comhead"><a href="user?id=henriquegodoy" class="hnuser">henriquegodoy</a> <span class="age" title="2025-08-07T18:41:00 1754592060"><a href="item?id=44828661">37 minutes ago</a></span> <span id="unv_44828661"></span><span class="navs">| <a href="#44828137" class="clicky" aria-hidden="true">prev</a> | <a href="#44827179" class="clicky" aria-hidden="true">next</a> <a class="togg clicky" id="44828661" n="2" href="javascript:void(0)">[–]</a><span class="onstory"></span></span></span></div><br><div class="comment"><div class="commtext c00">That SWE-bench chart with the mismatched bars (52.8% somehow appearing larger than 69.1%) was emblematic of the entire presentation - rushed and underwhelming. It's the kind of error that would get flagged in any internal review, yet here it is in a billion-dollar product launch. Combined with the Bernoulli effect demo confidently explaining how airplane wings work incorrectly (the equal transit time fallacy that NASA explicitly debunks), it doesn't inspire confidence in either the model's capabilities or OpenAI's quality control.<p>The actual benchmark improvements are marginal at best - we're talking single-digit percentage gains over o3 on most metrics, which hardly justifies a major version bump. What we're seeing looks more like the plateau of an S-curve than a breakthrough. The pricing is competitive ($1.25/1M input tokens vs Claude's $15), but that's about optimization and economics, not the fundamental leap forward that "GPT-5" implies. Even their "unified system" turns out to be multiple models with a router, essentially admitting that the end-to-end training approach has hit diminishing returns.</p><p>The irony is that while OpenAI maintains their secretive culture (remember when they claimed o1 used tree search instead of RL?), their competitors are catching up or surpassing them. Claude has been consistently better for coding tasks, Gemini 2.5 Pro has more recent training data, and everyone seems to be converging on similar performance levels. This launch feels less like a victory lap and more like OpenAI trying to maintain relevance while the rest of the field has caught up. Looking forward to seeing what Gemini 3.0 brings to the table.</p></div><div class="reply"><p><font size="1"><u><a href="reply?id=44828661&amp;goto=item%3Fid%3D44826997%2344828661" rel="nofollow">reply</a></u></font></p></div></div></td></tr></tbody></table>

<table border="0"><tbody><tr><td class="ind" indent="1"><img src="s.gif" height="1" width="40"></td><td valign="top" class="votelinks"><center><a id="up_44828936" href="vote?id=44828936&amp;how=up&amp;goto=item%3Fid%3D44826997"><div class="votearrow" title="upvote"></div></a></center></td><td class="default"><div style="margin-top:2px; margin-bottom:-10px;"><span class="comhead"><a href="user?id=rrrrrrrrrrrryan" class="hnuser">rrrrrrrrrrrryan</a> <span class="age" title="2025-08-07T19:03:41 1754593421"><a href="item?id=44828936">15 minutes ago</a></span> <span id="unv_44828936"></span><span class="navs">| <a href="#44828661" class="clicky" aria-hidden="true">parent</a> | <a href="#44827179" class="clicky" aria-hidden="true">next</a> <a class="togg clicky" id="44828936" n="1" href="javascript:void(0)">[–]</a><span class="onstory"></span></span></span></div><br><div class="comment"><div class="commtext c00">I suspect the vast majority of OpenAI's users are <i>only</i> using ChatGPT, and the vast majority of those ChatGPT users are <i>only</i> using the free tier.<p>For all of them, getting access to full-blown GPT-5 will probably be mind-blowing, even if it's severely rate-limited. OpenAI's previous/current generation of models haven't really been ergonomic enough (with the clunky model pickers) to be fully appreciated by less tech-savvy users, and its full capabilities have been behind a paywall.</p><p>I think that's why they're making this launch is a big deal. It's just an incremental upgrade for the power users and the people that are paying money, but it'll be a step-change in capability to everyone else.</p></div><div class="reply"><p><font size="1"><u><a href="reply?id=44828936&amp;goto=item%3Fid%3D44826997%2344828936" rel="nofollow">reply</a></u></font></p></div></div></td></tr></tbody></table>

<table border="0"><tbody><tr><td class="ind" indent="0"><img src="s.gif" height="1" width="0"></td><td valign="top" class="votelinks"><center><a id="up_44827179" href="vote?id=44827179&amp;how=up&amp;goto=item%3Fid%3D44826997"><div class="votearrow" title="upvote"></div></a></center></td><td class="default"><div style="margin-top:2px; margin-bottom:-10px;"><span class="comhead"><a href="user?id=mtlynch" class="hnuser">mtlynch</a> <span class="age" title="2025-08-07T17:10:12 1754586612"><a href="item?id=44827179">2 hours ago</a></span> <span id="unv_44827179"></span><span class="navs">| <a href="#44828661" class="clicky" aria-hidden="true">prev</a> | <a href="#44827210" class="clicky" aria-hidden="true">next</a> <a class="togg clicky" id="44827179" n="63" href="javascript:void(0)">[–]</a><span class="onstory"></span></span></span></div><br><div class="comment"><div class="commtext c00">What's going on with their SWE bench graph?[0]<p>GPT-5 non-thinking is labeled 52.8% accuracy, but o3 is shown as a much shorter bar, yet it's labeled 69.1%. And 4o is an identical bar to o3, but it's labeled 30.8%...</p><p>[0] <a href="https://i.postimg.cc/DzkZZLry/y-axis.png" rel="nofollow">https://i.postimg.cc/DzkZZLry/y-axis.png</a></p></div><div class="reply"><p><font size="1"><u><a href="reply?id=44827179&amp;goto=item%3Fid%3D44826997%2344827179" rel="nofollow">reply</a></u></font></p></div></div></td></tr></tbody></table>

<table border="0"><tbody><tr><td class="ind" indent="1"><img src="s.gif" height="1" width="40"></td><td valign="top" class="votelinks"><center><a id="up_44827409" href="vote?id=44827409&amp;how=up&amp;goto=item%3Fid%3D44826997"><div class="votearrow" title="upvote"></div></a></center></td><td class="default"><div style="margin-top:2px; margin-bottom:-10px;"><span class="comhead"><a href="user?id=Aurornis" class="hnuser">Aurornis</a> <span class="age" title="2025-08-07T17:23:25 1754587405"><a href="item?id=44827409">1 hour ago</a></span> <span id="unv_44827409"></span><span class="navs">| <a href="#44827179" class="clicky" aria-hidden="true">parent</a> | <a href="#44827623" class="clicky" aria-hidden="true">next</a> <a class="togg clicky" id="44827409" n="23" href="javascript:void(0)">[–]</a><span class="onstory"></span></span></span></div><br><div class="comment"><div class="commtext c00">As someone who spent years quadruple checking every figure in every slide for years to avoid a mistake like this, it’s very confusing to see this out of the big launch announcement of one of the most high profile startups around.<p>Even the small presentations we gave to execs or the board were checked for errors so many times that nothing could possibly slip through.</p></div><div class="reply"><p><font size="1"><u><a href="reply?id=44827409&amp;goto=item%3Fid%3D44826997%2344827409" rel="nofollow">reply</a></u></font></p></div></div></td></tr></tbody></table>

<table border="0"><tbody><tr><td class="ind" indent="2"><img src="s.gif" height="1" width="80"></td><td valign="top" class="votelinks"><center><a id="up_44827672" href="vote?id=44827672&amp;how=up&amp;goto=item%3Fid%3D44826997"><div class="votearrow" title="upvote"></div></a></center></td><td class="default"><div style="margin-top:2px; margin-bottom:-10px;"><span class="comhead"><a href="user?id=ertgbnm" class="hnuser">ertgbnm</a> <span class="age" title="2025-08-07T17:40:12 1754588412"><a href="item?id=44827672">1 hour ago</a></span> <span id="unv_44827672"></span><span class="navs">| <a href="#44827179" class="clicky" aria-hidden="true">root</a> | <a href="#44827409" class="clicky" aria-hidden="true">parent</a> | <a href="#44827598" class="clicky" aria-hidden="true">next</a> <a class="togg clicky" id="44827672" n="3" href="javascript:void(0)">[–]</a><span class="onstory"></span></span></span></div><br><div class="comment"><div class="commtext c00">It's literally a billion dollar plus release. I get more scrutiny on my presentations to groups of 10 people.</div><div class="reply"><p><font size="1"><u><a href="reply?id=44827672&amp;goto=item%3Fid%3D44826997%2344827672" rel="nofollow">reply</a></u></font></p></div></div></td></tr></tbody></table>

<table border="0"><tbody><tr><td class="ind" indent="3"><img src="s.gif" height="1" width="120"></td><td valign="top" class="votelinks"><center><a id="up_44827764" href="vote?id=44827764&amp;how=up&amp;goto=item%3Fid%3D44826997"><div class="votearrow" title="upvote"></div></a></center></td><td class="default"><div style="margin-top:2px; margin-bottom:-10px;"><span class="comhead"><a href="user?id=dbg31415" class="hnuser">dbg31415</a> <span class="age" title="2025-08-07T17:44:42 1754588682"><a href="item?id=44827764">1 hour ago</a></span> <span id="unv_44827764"></span><span class="navs">| <a href="#44827179" class="clicky" aria-hidden="true">root</a> | <a href="#44827672" class="clicky" aria-hidden="true">parent</a> | <a href="#44827598" class="clicky" aria-hidden="true">next</a> <a class="togg clicky" id="44827764" n="2" href="javascript:void(0)">[–]</a><span class="onstory"></span></span></span></div><br><div class="comment"><div class="commtext c5A">I take a strange comfort in still spotting AI typos. Makes it obvious their shiny new "toy" isn't ready to replace professionals.<p>They talk about using this to help families facing a cancer diagnosis -- literal life or death! -- and we're supposed to trust a machine that can't even spot a few simple typos? Ha.</p><p>The lack of human proofreading says more about their values than their capabilities. They don't want oversight -- especially not from human professionals.</p></div><div class="reply"><p><font size="1"><u><a href="reply?id=44827764&amp;goto=item%3Fid%3D44826997%2344827764" rel="nofollow">reply</a></u></font></p></div></div></td></tr></tbody></table>

<table border="0"><tbody><tr><td class="ind" indent="4"><img src="s.gif" height="1" width="160"></td><td valign="top" class="votelinks"><center><a id="up_44828437" href="vote?id=44828437&amp;how=up&amp;goto=item%3Fid%3D44826997"><div class="votearrow" title="upvote"></div></a></center></td><td class="default"><div style="margin-top:2px; margin-bottom:-10px;"><span class="comhead"><a href="user?id=nine_k" class="hnuser">nine_k</a> <span class="age" title="2025-08-07T18:25:18 1754591118"><a href="item?id=44828437">53 minutes ago</a></span> <span id="unv_44828437"></span><span class="navs">| <a href="#44827179" class="clicky" aria-hidden="true">root</a> | <a href="#44827764" class="clicky" aria-hidden="true">parent</a> | <a href="#44827598" class="clicky" aria-hidden="true">next</a> <a class="togg clicky" id="44828437" n="1" href="javascript:void(0)">[–]</a><span class="onstory"></span></span></span></div><br><div class="comment"><div class="commtext c00">Cynically, the AI <i>is</i> ready to replace professionals, in areas where the stakeholders don't care too much. They can offer the services cheaper, and this is <i>all</i> that matters to their customers. Were it not so, companies like Tata won't have any customers. The phenomenon of "cheap Chinese junk" would not exist, because no retailer would order to produce it.<p>So, brace yourselves, we'll see more of this in production :(</p></div><div class="reply"><p><font size="1"><u><a href="reply?id=44828437&amp;goto=item%3Fid%3D44826997%2344828437" rel="nofollow">reply</a></u></font></p></div></div></td></tr></tbody></table>

<table border="0"><tbody><tr><td class="ind" indent="1"><img src="s.gif" height="1" width="40"></td><td valign="top" class="votelinks"><center><a id="up_44828471" href="vote?id=44828471&amp;how=up&amp;goto=item%3Fid%3D44826997"><div class="votearrow" title="upvote"></div></a></center></td><td class="default"><div style="margin-top:2px; margin-bottom:-10px;"><span class="comhead"><a href="user?id=SkyPuncher" class="hnuser">SkyPuncher</a> <span class="age" title="2025-08-07T18:27:42 1754591262"><a href="item?id=44828471">51 minutes ago</a></span> <span id="unv_44828471"></span><span class="navs">| <a href="#44827210" class="clicky" aria-hidden="true">parent</a> | <a href="#44827376" class="clicky" aria-hidden="true">prev</a> | <a href="#44828673" class="clicky" aria-hidden="true">next</a> <a class="togg clicky" id="44828471" n="1" href="javascript:void(0)">[–]</a><span class="onstory"></span></span></span></div><br><div class="comment"><div class="commtext c00">That Bernoulli effect thing was a complete fail. It didn't work how they expected, at all.<p>I know that it's rather hard for them to demo the deep reasoning, but all of the demos felt like toys - rather that actual tools.</p></div><div class="reply"><p><font size="1"><u><a href="reply?id=44828471&amp;goto=item%3Fid%3D44826997%2344828471" rel="nofollow">reply</a></u></font></p></div></div></td></tr></tbody></table>

<table border="0"><tbody><tr><td class="ind" indent="1"><img src="s.gif" height="1" width="40"></td><td valign="top" class="votelinks"><center><a id="up_44828673" href="vote?id=44828673&amp;how=up&amp;goto=item%3Fid%3D44826997"><div class="votearrow" title="upvote"></div></a></center></td><td class="default"><div style="margin-top:2px; margin-bottom:-10px;"><span class="comhead"><a href="user?id=Mali-" class="hnuser">Mali-</a> <span class="age" title="2025-08-07T18:41:41 1754592101"><a href="item?id=44828673">37 minutes ago</a></span> <span id="unv_44828673"></span><span class="navs">| <a href="#44827210" class="clicky" aria-hidden="true">parent</a> | <a href="#44828471" class="clicky" aria-hidden="true">prev</a> | <a href="#44828665" class="clicky" aria-hidden="true">next</a> <a class="togg clicky" id="44828673" n="1" href="javascript:void(0)">[–]</a><span class="onstory"></span></span></span></div><br><div class="comment"><div class="commtext c00">The last part of GPT's answer does say: "Bernoulli's effect works alongside Newton's Third Law - the wing pushes air downward [...] - so the lift isn't only Bernoulli..."<p>According to this answer on physics stackexchange, Bernoulli accounts for 20% of the lift, so GPT's answer seems about right: <a href="https://physics.stackexchange.com/a/77977" rel="nofollow">https://physics.stackexchange.com/a/77977</a></p><p>I hope any future AI overlords see my charity</p></div><div class="reply"><p><font size="1"><u><a href="reply?id=44828673&amp;goto=item%3Fid%3D44826997%2344828673" rel="nofollow">reply</a></u></font></p></div></div></td></tr></tbody></table>

<table border="0"><tbody><tr><td class="ind" indent="1"><img src="s.gif" height="1" width="40"></td><td valign="top" class="votelinks"><center><a id="up_44828665" href="vote?id=44828665&amp;how=up&amp;goto=item%3Fid%3D44826997"><div class="votearrow" title="upvote"></div></a></center></td><td class="default"><div style="margin-top:2px; margin-bottom:-10px;"><span class="comhead"><a href="user?id=nwienert" class="hnuser">nwienert</a> <span class="age" title="2025-08-07T18:41:04 1754592064"><a href="item?id=44828665">37 minutes ago</a></span> <span id="unv_44828665"></span><span class="navs">| <a href="#44827210" class="clicky" aria-hidden="true">parent</a> | <a href="#44828673" class="clicky" aria-hidden="true">prev</a> | <a href="#44827342" class="clicky" aria-hidden="true">next</a> <a class="togg clicky" id="44828665" n="1" href="javascript:void(0)">[–]</a><span class="onstory"></span></span></span></div><br><div class="comment"><div class="commtext c00">Their code example underwhelmed too, the first one started out with 2/X progress, all of them looked terrible, third didn't have mouse icon.</div><div class="reply"><p><font size="1"><u><a href="reply?id=44828665&amp;goto=item%3Fid%3D44826997%2344828665" rel="nofollow">reply</a></u></font></p></div></div></td></tr></tbody></table>

<table border="0"><tbody><tr><td class="ind" indent="1"><img src="s.gif" height="1" width="40"></td><td valign="top" class="votelinks"><center><a id="up_44827342" href="vote?id=44827342&amp;how=up&amp;goto=item%3Fid%3D44826997"><div class="votearrow" title="upvote"></div></a></center></td><td class="default"><div style="margin-top:2px; margin-bottom:-10px;"><span class="comhead"><a href="user?id=dataflow" class="hnuser">dataflow</a> <span class="age" title="2025-08-07T17:19:00 1754587140"><a href="item?id=44827342">1 hour ago</a></span> <span id="unv_44827342"></span><span class="navs">| <a href="#44827210" class="clicky" aria-hidden="true">parent</a> | <a href="#44828665" class="clicky" aria-hidden="true">prev</a> | <a href="#44827241" class="clicky" aria-hidden="true">next</a> <a class="togg clicky" id="44827342" n="5" href="javascript:void(0)">[–]</a><span class="onstory"></span></span></span></div><br><div class="comment"><div class="commtext c00">Relevant: <a href="https://xkcd.com/803/" rel="nofollow">https://xkcd.com/803/</a><p>That said, I recall reading somewhere that it's a combination of effects, and the Bernoulli effect contributes, among many others. Never heard an explanation that left me completely satisfied, though. The one about deflecting air down was the one that always made sense to me even as a kid, but I can't believe that would be the only explanation - there has to be a good reason that gave rise to the Bernoulli effect as the popular explanation.</p><p>And you can tell that effect makes some sense of you hold a sheet of paper and blow air over it - it will rise. So any difference in air speed has to contribute.</p></div><div class="reply"><p><font size="1"><u><a href="reply?id=44827342&amp;goto=item%3Fid%3D44826997%2344827342" rel="nofollow">reply</a></u></font></p></div></div></td></tr></tbody></table>

<table border="0"><tbody><tr><td class="ind" indent="2"><img src="s.gif" height="1" width="80"></td><td valign="top" class="votelinks"><center><a id="up_44828694" href="vote?id=44828694&amp;how=up&amp;goto=item%3Fid%3D44826997"><div class="votearrow" title="upvote"></div></a></center></td><td class="default"><div style="margin-top:2px; margin-bottom:-10px;"><span class="comhead"><a href="user?id=semi-extrinsic" class="hnuser">semi-extrinsic</a> <span class="age" title="2025-08-07T18:43:24 1754592204"><a href="item?id=44828694">35 minutes ago</a></span> <span id="unv_44828694"></span><span class="navs">| <a href="#44827210" class="clicky" aria-hidden="true">root</a> | <a href="#44827342" class="clicky" aria-hidden="true">parent</a> | <a href="#44828461" class="clicky" aria-hidden="true">next</a> <a class="togg clicky" id="44828694" n="2" href="javascript:void(0)">[–]</a><span class="onstory"></span></span></span></div><br><div class="comment"><div class="commtext c00">What is <i>just plain wrong</i> is the equal transit time thing, people saying that air on both sides of the wing have to take the same time to pass it.<p>The Bernoulli effect as a separate entity is really a result of (over)simplification, but it's not wrong. You need to solve the Navier-Stokes equations for the flow around the wing, but there are many ways to simplify this - from CFD at different resolutions, via panel methods and potential theory, to just conservation of energy (which is the Bernoulli equation). So it gets popularized because it's the most simplified model.</p><p>To give an analogy, you can think of all CPUs as a von Neumann architecture. But the reality is that you have a hugely complicated thing with stacks, multiple cache levels, branch predictors, specex, yada yada.</p><p>On the very fundamental level, wings make air go down, and then airplane goes up. Just like you say. By using a curved airfoil instead of a flat plate, you can create more circulation in the flow, and then <i>because of the way fluids flow</i> you can get more lift and less drag.</p></div><div class="reply"><p><font size="1"><u><a href="reply?id=44828694&amp;goto=item%3Fid%3D44826997%2344828694" rel="nofollow">reply</a></u></font></p></div></div></td></tr></tbody></table>

<table border="0"><tbody><tr><td class="ind" indent="3"><img src="s.gif" height="1" width="120"></td><td valign="top" class="votelinks"><center><a id="up_44829063" href="vote?id=44829063&amp;how=up&amp;goto=item%3Fid%3D44826997"><div class="votearrow" title="upvote"></div></a></center></td><td class="default"><div style="margin-top:2px; margin-bottom:-10px;"><span class="comhead"><a href="user?id=carabiner" class="hnuser">carabiner</a> <span class="age" title="2025-08-07T19:14:52 1754594092"><a href="item?id=44829063">3 minutes ago</a></span> <span id="unv_44829063"></span><span class="navs">| <a href="#44827210" class="clicky" aria-hidden="true">root</a> | <a href="#44828694" class="clicky" aria-hidden="true">parent</a> | <a href="#44828461" class="clicky" aria-hidden="true">next</a> <a class="togg clicky" id="44829063" n="1" href="javascript:void(0)">[–]</a><span class="onstory"></span></span></span></div><br><div class="comment"><div class="commtext c00">Imagine an airfoil with a super tall square block on top of it. Due to equal transit time, the particles must accelerate to relativistic speeds to reach the end to rejoin the lower surface particles, when I point a house fan at it. We have created a magical flow accelerator!</div><div class="reply"><p><font size="1"><u><a href="reply?id=44829063&amp;goto=item%3Fid%3D44826997%2344829063" rel="nofollow">reply</a></u></font></p></div></div></td></tr></tbody></table>

<table border="0"><tbody><tr><td class="ind" indent="2"><img src="s.gif" height="1" width="80"></td><td valign="top" class="votelinks"><center><a id="up_44828461" href="vote?id=44828461&amp;how=up&amp;goto=item%3Fid%3D44826997"><div class="votearrow" title="upvote"></div></a></center></td><td class="default"><div style="margin-top:2px; margin-bottom:-10px;"><span class="comhead"><a href="user?id=adgjlsfhk1" class="hnuser">adgjlsfhk1</a> <span class="age" title="2025-08-07T18:27:06 1754591226"><a href="item?id=44828461">51 minutes ago</a></span> <span id="unv_44828461"></span><span class="navs">| <a href="#44827210" class="clicky" aria-hidden="true">root</a> | <a href="#44827342" class="clicky" aria-hidden="true">parent</a> | <a href="#44828694" class="clicky" aria-hidden="true">prev</a> | <a href="#44828057" class="clicky" aria-hidden="true">next</a> <a class="togg clicky" id="44828461" n="1" href="javascript:void(0)">[–]</a><span class="onstory"></span></span></span></div><br><div class="comment"><div class="commtext c00">the problem is that the "real" explanation is "solve navier stokes on the wing". everything else is just trying to build semi-reliable intuition.</div><div class="reply"><p><font size="1"><u><a href="reply?id=44828461&amp;goto=item%3Fid%3D44826997%2344828461" rel="nofollow">reply</a></u></font></p></div></div></td></tr></tbody></table>

<table border="0"><tbody><tr><td class="ind" indent="2"><img src="s.gif" height="1" width="80"></td><td valign="top" class="votelinks"><center><a id="up_44828057" href="vote?id=44828057&amp;how=up&amp;goto=item%3Fid%3D44826997"><div class="votearrow" title="upvote"></div></a></center></td><td class="default"><div style="margin-top:2px; margin-bottom:-10px;"><span class="comhead"><a href="user?id=amilios" class="hnuser">amilios</a> <span class="age" title="2025-08-07T18:00:53 1754589653"><a href="item?id=44828057">1 hour ago</a></span> <span id="unv_44828057"></span><span class="navs">| <a href="#44827210" class="clicky" aria-hidden="true">root</a> | <a href="#44827342" class="clicky" aria-hidden="true">parent</a> | <a href="#44828461" class="clicky" aria-hidden="true">prev</a> | <a href="#44827241" class="clicky" aria-hidden="true">next</a> <a class="togg clicky" id="44828057" n="1" href="javascript:void(0)">[–]</a><span class="onstory"></span></span></span></div><br><div class="comment"><div class="commtext c00">I believe the deflection is the high-level explanation. Things like the Bernoulli effect and the air on the top of the airfoil travelling faster (it does -- far faster than the equal transit time theory implies actually), are the "instantiation" or outcomes of the air deflection. This is my understanding. Hence airplanes can fly upside down because even if the airfoil is upside down, it's still deflecting the air, just perhaps less efficiently (I think it's true that planes flying upside down need a more extreme angle of attack to maintain lift, so this makes sense)</div><div class="reply"><p><font size="1"><u><a href="reply?id=44828057&amp;goto=item%3Fid%3D44826997%2344828057" rel="nofollow">reply</a></u></font></p></div></div></td></tr></tbody></table>

<table border="0"><tbody><tr><td class="ind" indent="1"><img src="s.gif" height="1" width="40"></td><td valign="top" class="votelinks"><center><a id="up_44827241" href="vote?id=44827241&amp;how=up&amp;goto=item%3Fid%3D44826997"><div class="votearrow" title="upvote"></div></a></center></td><td class="default"><div style="margin-top:2px; margin-bottom:-10px;"><span class="comhead"><a href="user?id=twixfel" class="hnuser">twixfel</a> <span class="age" title="2025-08-07T17:13:43 1754586823"><a href="item?id=44827241">2 hours ago</a></span> <span id="unv_44827241"></span><span class="navs">| <a href="#44827210" class="clicky" aria-hidden="true">parent</a> | <a href="#44827342" class="clicky" aria-hidden="true">prev</a> | <a href="#44827565" class="clicky" aria-hidden="true">next</a> <a class="togg clicky" id="44827241" n="6" href="javascript:void(0)">[–]</a><span class="onstory"></span></span></span></div><br><div class="comment"><div class="commtext c00">That's what I thought. Aeroplanes don't fly because of the Bernoulli effect:<p><a href="https://physics.stackexchange.com/questions/290/what-really-allows-airplanes-to-fly" rel="nofollow">https://physics.stackexchange.com/questions/290/what-really-...</a></p><p>Apparently. Not that I know either way.</p></div><div class="reply"><p><font size="1"><u><a href="reply?id=44827241&amp;goto=item%3Fid%3D44826997%2344827241" rel="nofollow">reply</a></u></font></p></div></div></td></tr></tbody></table>

<table border="0"><tbody><tr><td class="ind" indent="2"><img src="s.gif" height="1" width="80"></td><td valign="top" class="votelinks"><center><a id="up_44827380" href="vote?id=44827380&amp;how=up&amp;goto=item%3Fid%3D44826997"><div class="votearrow" title="upvote"></div></a></center></td><td class="default"><div style="margin-top:2px; margin-bottom:-10px;"><span class="comhead"><a href="user?id=QuantumGood" class="hnuser">QuantumGood</a> <span class="age" title="2025-08-07T17:21:28 1754587288"><a href="item?id=44827380">1 hour ago</a></span> <span id="unv_44827380"></span><span class="navs">| <a href="#44827210" class="clicky" aria-hidden="true">root</a> | <a href="#44827241" class="clicky" aria-hidden="true">parent</a> | <a href="#44827565" class="clicky" aria-hidden="true">next</a> <a class="togg clicky" id="44827380" n="5" href="javascript:void(0)">[–]</a><span class="onstory"></span></span></span></div><br><div class="comment"><div class="commtext c00">All things that create lift, lift the wings—and you need them all for efficient flight. <table border="0"><tbody><tr><td class="ind" indent="0"><img src="s.gif" height="1" width="0"></td><td valign="top" class="votelinks"><center><a id="up_44827857" href="vote?id=44827857&amp;how=up&amp;goto=item%3Fid%3D44826997"><div class="votearrow" title="upvote"></div></a></center></td><td class="default"><div style="margin-top:2px; margin-bottom:-10px;"><span class="comhead"><a href="user?id=fidotron" class="hnuser">fidotron</a> <span class="age" title="2025-08-07T17:49:31 1754588971"><a href="item?id=44827857">1 hour ago</a></span> <span id="unv_44827857"></span><span class="navs">| <a href="#44828264" class="clicky" aria-hidden="true">prev</a> | <a href="#44827929" class="clicky" aria-hidden="true">next</a> <a class="togg clicky" id="44827857" n="14" href="javascript:void(0)">[–]</a><span class="onstory"></span></span></span></div><br><div class="comment"><div class="commtext c00">Going by the system card at: <a href="https://openai.com/index/gpt-5-system-card/" rel="nofollow">https://openai.com/index/gpt-5-system-card/</a><p>&gt; GPT‑5 is a unified system . . .</p><p>OK</p><p>&gt; . . . with a smart and fast model that answers most questions, a deeper reasoning model for harder problems, and a real-time router that quickly decides which model to use based on conversation type, complexity, tool needs, and explicit intent (for example, if you say “think hard about this” in the prompt).</p><p>So that's not really a unified system then, it's just supposed to appear as if it is.</p><p>This looks like they're not training the single big model but instead have gone off to develop special sub models and attempt to gloss over them with yet another model. That's what you resort to only when doing the end-to-end training has become too expensive for you.</p></div><div class="reply"><p><font size="1"><u><a href="reply?id=44827857&amp;goto=item%3Fid%3D44826997%2344827857" rel="nofollow">reply</a></u></font></p></div></div></td></tr></tbody></table>

<table border="0"><tbody><tr><td class="ind" indent="1"><img src="s.gif" height="1" width="40"></td><td valign="top" class="votelinks"><center><a id="up_44829101" href="vote?id=44829101&amp;how=up&amp;goto=item%3Fid%3D44826997"><div class="votearrow" title="upvote"></div></a></center></td><td class="default"><div style="margin-top:2px; margin-bottom:-10px;"><span class="comhead"><a href="user?id=hatthew" class="hnuser">hatthew</a> <span class="age" title="2025-08-07T19:17:18 1754594238"><a href="item?id=44829101">1 minute ago</a></span> <span id="unv_44829101"></span><span class="navs">| <a href="#44827857" class="clicky" aria-hidden="true">parent</a> | <a href="#44828224" class="clicky" aria-hidden="true">next</a> <a class="togg clicky" id="44829101" n="1" href="javascript:void(0)">[–]</a><span class="onstory"></span></span></span></div><br><div class="comment"><div class="commtext c00">I know this is just arguing semantics, but wouldn't you call it a unified system since it has a single interface that automatically interacts with different components? It's not a unified <i>model</i>, but it seems correct to call it a unified <i>system</i>.</div><div class="reply"><p><font size="1"><u><a href="reply?id=44829101&amp;goto=item%3Fid%3D44826997%2344829101" rel="nofollow">reply</a></u></font></p></div></div></td></tr></tbody></table>

<table border="0"><tbody><tr><td class="ind" indent="1"><img src="s.gif" height="1" width="40"></td><td valign="top" class="votelinks"><center><a id="up_44828224" href="vote?id=44828224&amp;how=up&amp;goto=item%3Fid%3D44826997"><div class="votearrow" title="upvote"></div></a></center></td><td class="default"><div style="margin-top:2px; margin-bottom:-10px;"><span class="comhead"><a href="user?id=Therenas" class="hnuser">Therenas</a> <span class="age" title="2025-08-07T18:11:13 1754590273"><a href="item?id=44828224">1 hour ago</a></span> <span id="unv_44828224"></span><span class="navs">| <a href="#44827857" class="clicky" aria-hidden="true">parent</a> | <a href="#44829101" class="clicky" aria-hidden="true">prev</a> | <a href="#44827905" class="clicky" aria-hidden="true">next</a> <a class="togg clicky" id="44828224" n="2" href="javascript:void(0)">[–]</a><span class="onstory"></span></span></span></div><br><div class="comment"><div class="commtext c00">Too expensive maybe, or just not effective anymore as they used up any available training data. New data is generated slowly, and is massively poisoned with AI generated data, so it might be useless.</div><div class="reply"><p><font size="1"><u><a href="reply?id=44828224&amp;goto=item%3Fid%3D44826997%2344828224" rel="nofollow">reply</a></u></font></p></div></div></td></tr></tbody></table>

<table border="0"><tbody><tr><td class="ind" indent="2"><img src="s.gif" height="1" width="80"></td><td valign="top" class="votelinks"><center><a id="up_44828411" href="vote?id=44828411&amp;how=up&amp;goto=item%3Fid%3D44826997"><div class="votearrow" title="upvote"></div></a></center></td><td class="default"><div style="margin-top:2px; margin-bottom:-10px;"><span class="comhead"><a href="user?id=fidotron" class="hnuser">fidotron</a> <span class="age" title="2025-08-07T18:23:31 1754591011"><a href="item?id=44828411">55 minutes ago</a></span> <span id="unv_44828411"></span><span class="navs">| <a href="#44827857" class="clicky" aria-hidden="true">root</a> | <a href="#44828224" class="clicky" aria-hidden="true">parent</a> | <a href="#44827905" class="clicky" aria-hidden="true">next</a> <a class="togg clicky" id="44828411" n="1" href="javascript:void(0)">[–]</a><span class="onstory"></span></span></span></div><br><div class="comment"><div class="commtext c00">I think that possibility is worse, because it implies a fundamental limit as opposed to a self imposed restriction, and I choose to remain optimistic.<p>If OpenAI really are hitting the wall on being able to scale up overall then the AI bubble will burst sooner than many are expecting.</p></div><div class="reply"><p><font size="1"><u><a href="reply?id=44828411&amp;goto=item%3Fid%3D44826997%2344828411" rel="nofollow">reply</a></u></font></p></div></div></td></tr></tbody></table>

<table border="0"><tbody><tr><td class="ind" indent="1"><img src="s.gif" height="1" width="40"></td><td valign="top" class="votelinks"><center><a id="up_44827905" href="vote?id=44827905&amp;how=up&amp;goto=item%3Fid%3D44826997"><div class="votearrow" title="upvote"></div></a></center></td><td class="default"><div style="margin-top:2px; margin-bottom:-10px;"><span class="comhead"><a href="user?id=lacoolj" class="hnuser">lacoolj</a> <span class="age" title="2025-08-07T17:52:18 1754589138"><a href="item?id=44827905">1 hour ago</a></span> <span id="unv_44827905"></span><span class="navs">| <a href="#44827857" class="clicky" aria-hidden="true">parent</a> | <a href="#44828224" class="clicky" aria-hidden="true">prev</a> | <a href="#44828116" class="clicky" aria-hidden="true">next</a> <a class="togg clicky" id="44827905" n="6" href="javascript:void(0)">[–]</a><span class="onstory"></span></span></span></div><br><div class="comment"><div class="commtext c00">Many tiny, specialized models is the way to go, and if that's what they're doing then it's a good thing.</div><div class="reply"><p><font size="1"><u><a href="reply?id=44827905&amp;goto=item%3Fid%3D44826997%2344827905" rel="nofollow">reply</a></u></font></p></div></div></td></tr></tbody></table>

<table border="0"><tbody><tr><td class="ind" indent="2"><img src="s.gif" height="1" width="80"></td><td valign="top" class="votelinks"><center><a id="up_44828106" href="vote?id=44828106&amp;how=up&amp;goto=item%3Fid%3D44826997"><div class="votearrow" title="upvote"></div></a></center></td><td class="default"><div style="margin-top:2px; margin-bottom:-10px;"><span class="comhead"><a href="user?id=fidotron" class="hnuser">fidotron</a> <span class="age" title="2025-08-07T18:03:42 1754589822"><a href="item?id=44828106">1 hour ago</a></span> <span id="unv_44828106"></span><span class="navs">| <a href="#44827857" class="clicky" aria-hidden="true">root</a> | <a href="#44827905" class="clicky" aria-hidden="true">parent</a> | <a href="#44828114" class="clicky" aria-hidden="true">next</a> <a class="togg clicky" id="44828106" n="3" href="javascript:void(0)">[–]</a><span class="onstory"></span></span></span></div><br><div class="comment"><div class="commtext c00">Not at all, you will simply rediscover the bitter lesson [1] from your new composition of models.<p>[1] <a href="https://www.cs.utexas.edu/~eunsol/courses/data/bitter_lesson.pdf" rel="nofollow">https://www.cs.utexas.edu/~eunsol/courses/data/bitter_lesson...</a></p></div><div class="reply"><p><font size="1"><u><a href="reply?id=44828106&amp;goto=item%3Fid%3D44826997%2344828106" rel="nofollow">reply</a></u></font></p></div></div></td></tr></tbody></table>

<table border="0"><tbody><tr><td class="ind" indent="3"><img src="s.gif" height="1" width="120"></td><td valign="top" class="votelinks"><center><a id="up_44828308" href="vote?id=44828308&amp;how=up&amp;goto=item%3Fid%3D44826997"><div class="votearrow" title="upvote"></div></a></center></td><td class="default"><div style="margin-top:2px; margin-bottom:-10px;"><span class="comhead"><a href="user?id=bigmadshoe" class="hnuser">bigmadshoe</a> <span class="age" title="2025-08-07T18:16:16 1754590576"><a href="item?id=44828308">1 hour ago</a></span> <span id="unv_44828308"></span><span class="navs">| <a href="#44827857" class="clicky" aria-hidden="true">root</a> | <a href="#44828106" class="clicky" aria-hidden="true">parent</a> | <a href="#44828114" class="clicky" aria-hidden="true">next</a> <a class="togg clicky" id="44828308" n="2" href="javascript:void(0)">[–]</a><span class="onstory"></span></span></span></div><br><div class="comment"><div class="commtext c00">The bitter lesson doesn't say that you can't split your solution into multiple models. It says that learning from more data via scaled compute will outperform humans injecting their own assumptions about the task into models.<p>A broad generalization like "there are two systems of thinking: fast, and slow" doesn't necessarily fall into this category. The transformer itself (plus the choice of positional encoding etc.) contains inductive biases about modeling sequences. The router is presumably still learned with a fairly generic architecture.</p></div><div class="reply"><p><font size="1"><u><a href="reply?id=44828308&amp;goto=item%3Fid%3D44826997%2344828308" rel="nofollow">reply</a></u></font></p></div></div></td></tr></tbody></table>

<table border="0"><tbody><tr><td class="ind" indent="4"><img src="s.gif" height="1" width="160"></td><td valign="top" class="votelinks"><center><a id="up_44828350" href="vote?id=44828350&amp;how=up&amp;goto=item%3Fid%3D44826997"><div class="votearrow" title="upvote"></div></a></center></td><td class="default"><div style="margin-top:2px; margin-bottom:-10px;"><span class="comhead"><a href="user?id=fidotron" class="hnuser">fidotron</a> <span class="age" title="2025-08-07T18:19:09 1754590749"><a href="item?id=44828350">59 minutes ago</a></span> <span id="unv_44828350"></span><span class="navs">| <a href="#44827857" class="clicky" aria-hidden="true">root</a> | <a href="#44828308" class="clicky" aria-hidden="true">parent</a> | <a href="#44828114" class="clicky" aria-hidden="true">next</a> <a class="togg clicky" id="44828350" n="1" href="javascript:void(0)">[–]</a><span class="onstory"></span></span></span></div><br><div class="comment"><div class="commtext c00">&gt; It says that learning from more data via scaled compute will outperform humans injecting their own assumptions about the task into models.<p>You are making assumptions about how to break the tasks into sub models.</p></div><div class="reply"><p><font size="1"><u><a href="reply?id=44828350&amp;goto=item%3Fid%3D44826997%2344828350" rel="nofollow">reply</a></u></font></p></div></div></td></tr></tbody></table>

<table border="0"><tbody><tr><td class="ind" indent="2"><img src="s.gif" height="1" width="80"></td><td valign="top" class="votelinks"><center><a id="up_44828114" href="vote?id=44828114&amp;how=up&amp;goto=item%3Fid%3D44826997"><div class="votearrow" title="upvote"></div></a></center></td><td class="default"><div style="margin-top:2px; margin-bottom:-10px;"><span class="comhead"><a href="user?id=gekoxyz" class="hnuser">gekoxyz</a> <span class="age" title="2025-08-07T18:04:11 1754589851"><a href="item?id=44828114">1 hour ago</a></span> <span id="unv_44828114"></span><span class="navs">| <a href="#44827857" class="clicky" aria-hidden="true">root</a> | <a href="#44827905" class="clicky" aria-hidden="true">parent</a> | <a href="#44828106" class="clicky" aria-hidden="true">prev</a> | <a href="#44828116" class="clicky" aria-hidden="true">next</a> <a class="togg clicky" id="44828114" n="2" href="javascript:void(0)">[–]</a><span class="onstory"></span></span></span></div><br><div class="comment"><div class="commtext c5A">We already did this for Object/Face recognition, it works but it's not the way to go. It's the way to go only if you don't have enough compute power (and data, I suspect) for a E2E network</div><div class="reply"><p><font size="1"><u><a href="reply?id=44828114&amp;goto=item%3Fid%3D44826997%2344828114" rel="nofollow">reply</a></u></font></p></div></div></td></tr></tbody></table>

<table border="0"><tbody><tr><td class="ind" indent="3"><img src="s.gif" height="1" width="120"></td><td valign="top" class="votelinks"><center><a id="up_44828188" href="vote?id=44828188&amp;how=up&amp;goto=item%3Fid%3D44826997"><div class="votearrow" title="upvote"></div></a></center></td><td class="default"><div style="margin-top:2px; margin-bottom:-10px;"><span class="comhead"><a href="user?id=sixo" class="hnuser">sixo</a> <span class="age" title="2025-08-07T18:09:08 1754590148"><a href="item?id=44828188">1 hour ago</a></span> <span id="unv_44828188"></span><span class="navs">| <a href="#44827857" class="clicky" aria-hidden="true">root</a> | <a href="#44828114" class="clicky" aria-hidden="true">parent</a> | <a href="#44828116" class="clicky" aria-hidden="true">next</a> <a class="togg clicky" id="44828188" n="1" href="javascript:void(0)">[–]</a><span class="onstory"></span></span></span></div><br><div class="comment"><div class="commtext c00">No, it's what you do if your model architecture is capped out on its ability to profit from further training. Hand-wrapping a bunch of sub-models stands in for models that can learn that kind of substructure directly.</div><div class="reply"><p><font size="1"><u><a href="reply?id=44828188&amp;goto=item%3Fid%3D44826997%2344828188" rel="nofollow">reply</a></u></font></p></div></div></td></tr></tbody></table>

<table border="0"><tbody><tr><td class="ind" indent="1"><img src="s.gif" height="1" width="40"></td><td valign="top" class="votelinks"><center><a id="up_44828116" href="vote?id=44828116&amp;how=up&amp;goto=item%3Fid%3D44826997"><div class="votearrow" title="upvote"></div></a></center></td><td class="default"><div style="margin-top:2px; margin-bottom:-10px;"><span class="comhead"><a href="user?id=TheOtherHobbes" class="hnuser">TheOtherHobbes</a> <span class="age" title="2025-08-07T18:04:11 1754589851"><a href="item?id=44828116">1 hour ago</a></span> <span id="unv_44828116"></span><span class="navs">| <a href="#44827857" class="clicky" aria-hidden="true">parent</a> | <a href="#44827905" class="clicky" aria-hidden="true">prev</a> | <a href="#44828502" class="clicky" aria-hidden="true">next</a> <a class="togg clicky" id="44828116" n="1" href="javascript:void(0)">[–]</a><span class="onstory"></span></span></span></div><br><div class="comment"><div class="commtext c00">It's a concept of a unified system.</div><div class="reply"><p><font size="1"><u><a href="reply?id=44828116&amp;goto=item%3Fid%3D44826997%2344828116" rel="nofollow">reply</a></u></font></p></div></div></td></tr></tbody></table>

<table border="0"><tbody><tr><td class="ind" indent="1"><img src="s.gif" height="1" width="40"></td><td valign="top" class="votelinks"><center><a id="up_44828502" href="vote?id=44828502&amp;how=up&amp;goto=item%3Fid%3D44826997"><div class="votearrow" title="upvote"></div></a></center></td><td class="default"><div style="margin-top:2px; margin-bottom:-10px;"><span class="comhead"><a href="user?id=andai" class="hnuser">andai</a> <span class="age" title="2025-08-07T18:29:37 1754591377"><a href="item?id=44828502">49 minutes ago</a></span> <span id="unv_44828502"></span><span class="navs">| <a href="#44827857" class="clicky" aria-hidden="true">parent</a> | <a href="#44828116" class="clicky" aria-hidden="true">prev</a> | <a href="#44828074" class="clicky" aria-hidden="true">next</a> <a class="togg clicky" id="44828502" n="1" href="javascript:void(0)">[–]</a><span class="onstory"></span></span></span></div><br><div class="comment"><div class="commtext c00">&gt; While GPT‑5 in ChatGPT is a system of reasoning, non-reasoning, and router models, GPT‑5 in the API platform is the reasoning model that powers maximum performance in ChatGPT. Notably, GPT‑5 with minimal reasoning is a different model than the non-reasoning model in ChatGPT, and is better tuned for developers. The non-reasoning model used in ChatGPT is available as gpt-5-chat-latest.<p><a href="https://openai.com/index/introducing-gpt-5-for-developers/" rel="nofollow">https://openai.com/index/introducing-gpt-5-for-developers/</a></p></div><div class="reply"><p><font size="1"><u><a href="reply?id=44828502&amp;goto=item%3Fid%3D44826997%2344828502" rel="nofollow">reply</a></u></font></p></div></div></td></tr></tbody></table>

<table border="0"><tbody><tr><td class="ind" indent="1"><img src="s.gif" height="1" width="40"></td><td valign="top" class="votelinks"><center><a id="up_44828074" href="vote?id=44828074&amp;how=up&amp;goto=item%3Fid%3D44826997"><div class="votearrow" title="upvote"></div></a></center></td><td class="default"><div style="margin-top:2px; margin-bottom:-10px;"><span class="comhead"><a href="user?id=dang" class="hnuser">dang</a> <span class="age" title="2025-08-07T18:02:11 1754589731"><a href="item?id=44828074">1 hour ago</a></span> <span id="unv_44828074"></span><span class="navs">| <a href="#44827857" class="clicky" aria-hidden="true">parent</a> | <a href="#44828502" class="clicky" aria-hidden="true">prev</a> | <a href="#44828470" class="clicky" aria-hidden="true">next</a> <a class="togg clicky" id="44828074" n="1" href="javascript:void(0)">[–]</a><span class="onstory"></span></span></span></div><br><div class="comment"><div class="commtext c00">Related ongoing thread:<p><i>GPT-5 System Card [pdf]</i> - <a href="https://news.ycombinator.com/item?id=44827046">https://news.ycombinator.com/item?id=44827046</a></p></div><div class="reply"><p><font size="1"><u><a href="reply?id=44828074&amp;goto=item%3Fid%3D44826997%2344828074" rel="nofollow">reply</a></u></font></p></div></div></td></tr></tbody></table>

<table border="0"><tbody><tr><td class="ind" indent="1"><img src="s.gif" height="1" width="40"></td><td valign="top" class="votelinks"><center><a id="up_44828470" href="vote?id=44828470&amp;how=up&amp;goto=item%3Fid%3D44826997"><div class="votearrow" title="upvote"></div></a></center></td><td class="default"><div style="margin-top:2px; margin-bottom:-10px;"><span class="comhead"><a href="user?id=FeepingCreature" class="hnuser">FeepingCreature</a> <span class="age" title="2025-08-07T18:27:36 1754591256"><a href="item?id=44828470">51 minutes ago</a></span> <span id="unv_44828470"></span><span class="navs">| <a href="#44827857" class="clicky" aria-hidden="true">parent</a> | <a href="#44828074" class="clicky" aria-hidden="true">prev</a> | <a href="#44827929" class="clicky" aria-hidden="true">next</a> <a class="togg clicky" id="44828470" n="1" href="javascript:void(0)">[–]</a><span class="onstory"></span></span></span></div><br><div class="comment"><div class="commtext c00">If(f) it's trained end to end, it's a unified system.</div><div class="reply"><p><font size="1"><u><a href="reply?id=44828470&amp;goto=item%3Fid%3D44826997%2344828470" rel="nofollow">reply</a></u></font></p></div></div></td></tr></tbody></table>

<table border="0"><tbody><tr><td class="ind" indent="0"><img src="s.gif" height="1" width="0"></td><td valign="top" class="votelinks"><center><a id="up_44827929" href="vote?id=44827929&amp;how=up&amp;goto=item%3Fid%3D44826997"><div class="votearrow" title="upvote"></div></a></center></td><td class="default"><div style="margin-top:2px; margin-bottom:-10px;"><span class="comhead"><a href="user?id=surround" class="hnuser">surround</a> <span class="age" title="2025-08-07T17:53:29 1754589209"><a href="item?id=44827929">1 hour ago</a></span> <span id="unv_44827929"></span><span class="navs">| <a href="#44827857" class="clicky" aria-hidden="true">prev</a> | <a href="#44829109" class="clicky" aria-hidden="true">next</a> <a class="togg clicky" id="44827929" n="12" href="javascript:void(0)">[–]</a><span class="onstory"></span></span></span></div><br><div class="comment"><div class="commtext c00">GPT-5 knowledge cutoff: Sep 30, 2024 (10 months before release).<p>Compare that to</p><p>Gemini 2.5 Pro knowledge cutoff: Jan 2025 (3 months before release)</p><p>Claude Opus 4.1: knowledge cutoff: Mar 2025 (4 months before release)</p><p><a href="https://platform.openai.com/docs/models/compare" rel="nofollow">https://platform.openai.com/docs/models/compare</a></p><p><a href="https://deepmind.google/models/gemini/pro/" rel="nofollow">https://deepmind.google/models/gemini/pro/</a></p><p><a href="https://docs.anthropic.com/en/docs/about-claude/models/overview" rel="nofollow">https://docs.anthropic.com/en/docs/about-claude/models/overv...</a></p></div><div class="reply"><p><font size="1"><u><a href="reply?id=44827929&amp;goto=item%3Fid%3D44826997%2344827929" rel="nofollow">reply</a></u></font></p></div></div></td></tr></tbody></table>

<table border="0"><tbody><tr><td class="ind" indent="1"><img src="s.gif" height="1" width="40"></td><td valign="top" class="votelinks"><center><a id="up_44828345" href="vote?id=44828345&amp;how=up&amp;goto=item%3Fid%3D44826997"><div class="votearrow" title="upvote"></div></a></center></td><td class="default"><div style="margin-top:2px; margin-bottom:-10px;"><span class="comhead"><a href="user?id=levocardia" class="hnuser">levocardia</a> <span class="age" title="2025-08-07T18:18:37 1754590717"><a href="item?id=44828345">1 hour ago</a></span> <span id="unv_44828345"></span><span class="navs">| <a href="#44827929" class="clicky" aria-hidden="true">parent</a> | <a href="#44828446" class="clicky" aria-hidden="true">next</a> <a class="togg clicky" id="44828345" n="7" href="javascript:void(0)">[–]</a><span class="onstory"></span></span></span></div><br><div class="comment"><div class="commtext c00">with web search, is knowledge cutoff really relevant anymore? Or is this more of a comment on how long it took them to do post-training?</div><div class="reply"><p><font size="1"><u><a href="reply?id=44828345&amp;goto=item%3Fid%3D44826997%2344828345" rel="nofollow">reply</a></u></font></p></div></div></td></tr></tbody></table>

<table border="0"><tbody><tr><td class="ind" indent="2"><img src="s.gif" height="1" width="80"></td><td valign="top" class="votelinks"><center><a id="up_44829108" href="vote?id=44829108&amp;how=up&amp;goto=item%3Fid%3D44826997"><div class="votearrow" title="upvote"></div></a></center></td><td class="default"><div style="margin-top:2px; margin-bottom:-10px;"><span class="comhead"><a href="user?id=havefunbesafe" class="hnuser">havefunbesafe</a> <span class="age" title="2025-08-07T19:17:54 1754594274"><a href="item?id=44829108">0 minutes ago</a></span> <span id="unv_44829108"></span><span class="navs">| <a href="#44827929" class="clicky" aria-hidden="true">root</a> | <a href="#44828345" class="clicky" aria-hidden="true">parent</a> | <a href="#44828882" class="clicky" aria-hidden="true">next</a> <a class="togg clicky" id="44829108" n="1" href="javascript:void(0)">[–]</a><span class="onstory"></span></span></span></div><br><div class="comment"><div class="commtext c00">Question: do web search results that GPT kick back get "read" and backpropagated into the model?</div><div class="reply"><p><font size="1"><u><a href="reply?id=44829108&amp;goto=item%3Fid%3D44826997%2344829108" rel="nofollow">reply</a></u></font></p></div></div></td></tr></tbody></table>

<table border="0"><tbody><tr><td class="ind" indent="2"><img src="s.gif" height="1" width="80"></td><td valign="top" class="votelinks"><center><a id="up_44828882" href="vote?id=44828882&amp;how=up&amp;goto=item%3Fid%3D44826997"><div class="votearrow" title="upvote"></div></a></center></td><td class="default"><div style="margin-top:2px; margin-bottom:-10px;"><span class="comhead"><a href="user?id=MisterSandman" class="hnuser">MisterSandman</a> <span class="age" title="2025-08-07T18:59:36 1754593176"><a href="item?id=44828882">19 minutes ago</a></span> <span id="unv_44828882"></span><span class="navs">| <a href="#44827929" class="clicky" aria-hidden="true">root</a> | <a href="#44828345" class="clicky" aria-hidden="true">parent</a> | <a href="#44829108" class="clicky" aria-hidden="true">prev</a> | <a href="#44828465" class="clicky" aria-hidden="true">next</a> <a class="togg clicky" id="44828882" n="1" href="javascript:void(0)">[–]</a><span class="onstory"></span></span></span></div><br><div class="comment"><div class="commtext c00">It still is, not all queries trigger web search, and it takes more tokens and time to do research. ChatGPT will confidently give me outdated information, and unless I know it’s wrong and ask it to research, it wouldn’t know it is wrong. Having a more recent knowledge base can be very useful (for example, knowing who the president is without looking it up, making references to newer node versions instead of old ones)</div><div class="reply"><p><font size="1"><u><a href="reply?id=44828882&amp;goto=item%3Fid%3D44826997%2344828882" rel="nofollow">reply</a></u></font></p></div></div></td></tr></tbody></table>

<table border="0"><tbody><tr><td class="ind" indent="2"><img src="s.gif" height="1" width="80"></td><td valign="top" class="votelinks"><center><a id="up_44828465" href="vote?id=44828465&amp;how=up&amp;goto=item%3Fid%3D44826997"><div class="votearrow" title="upvote"></div></a></center></td><td class="default"><div style="margin-top:2px; margin-bottom:-10px;"><span class="comhead"><a href="user?id=mastercheif" class="hnuser">mastercheif</a> <span class="age" title="2025-08-07T18:27:11 1754591231"><a href="item?id=44828465">51 minutes ago</a></span> <span id="unv_44828465"></span><span class="navs">| <a href="#44827929" class="clicky" aria-hidden="true">root</a> | <a href="#44828345" class="clicky" aria-hidden="true">parent</a> | <a href="#44828882" class="clicky" aria-hidden="true">prev</a> | <a href="#44828509" class="clicky" aria-hidden="true">next</a> <a class="togg clicky" id="44828465" n="2" href="javascript:void(0)">[–]</a><span class="onstory"></span></span></span></div><br><div class="comment"><div class="commtext c00">In my experience, web search often tanks the quality of the output.<p>I don't know if it's because of context clogging or that the model can't tell what's a high quality source from garbage.</p><p>I've defaulted to web search off and turn it on via the tools menu as needed.</p></div><div class="reply"><p><font size="1"><u><a href="reply?id=44828465&amp;goto=item%3Fid%3D44826997%2344828465" rel="nofollow">reply</a></u></font></p></div></div></td></tr></tbody></table>

<table border="0"><tbody><tr><td class="ind" indent="3"><img src="s.gif" height="1" width="120"></td><td valign="top" class="votelinks"><center><a id="up_44828557" href="vote?id=44828557&amp;how=up&amp;goto=item%3Fid%3D44826997"><div class="votearrow" title="upvote"></div></a></center></td><td class="default"><div style="margin-top:2px; margin-bottom:-10px;"><span class="comhead"><a href="user?id=bangaladore" class="hnuser">bangaladore</a> <span class="age" title="2025-08-07T18:33:50 1754591630"><a href="item?id=44828557">44 minutes ago</a></span> <span id="unv_44828557"></span><span class="navs">| <a href="#44827929" class="clicky" aria-hidden="true">root</a> | <a href="#44828465" class="clicky" aria-hidden="true">parent</a> | <a href="#44828509" class="clicky" aria-hidden="true">next</a> <a class="togg clicky" id="44828557" n="1" href="javascript:void(0)">[–]</a><span class="onstory"></span></span></span></div><br><div class="comment"><div class="commtext c00">I feel the same. LLMs using web search ironically seem to have less thoughtful output. Part of the reason for using LLMs is to explore somewhat novel ideas. I think with web search it aligns too strongly to the results rather than the overall request making it a slow search-engine.</div><div class="reply"><p><font size="1"><u><a href="reply?id=44828557&amp;goto=item%3Fid%3D44826997%2344828557" rel="nofollow">reply</a></u></font></p></div></div></td></tr></tbody></table>

<table border="0"><tbody><tr><td class="ind" indent="2"><img src="s.gif" height="1" width="80"></td><td valign="top" class="votelinks"><center><a id="up_44828509" href="vote?id=44828509&amp;how=up&amp;goto=item%3Fid%3D44826997"><div class="votearrow" title="upvote"></div></a></center></td><td class="default"><div style="margin-top:2px; margin-bottom:-10px;"><span class="comhead"><a href="user?id=joshuacc" class="hnuser">joshuacc</a> <span class="age" title="2025-08-07T18:30:32 1754591432"><a href="item?id=44828509">48 minutes ago</a></span> <span id="unv_44828509"></span><span class="navs">| <a href="#44827929" class="clicky" aria-hidden="true">root</a> | <a href="#44828345" class="clicky" aria-hidden="true">parent</a> | <a href="#44828465" class="clicky" aria-hidden="true">prev</a> | <a href="#44828476" class="clicky" aria-hidden="true">next</a> <a class="togg clicky" id="44828509" n="1" href="javascript:void(0)">[–]</a><span class="onstory"></span></span></span></div><br><div class="comment"><div class="commtext c00">Still relevant, as it means that a coding agent is more likely to get things right without searching.
