<table border="0"><tbody><tr><td class="ind" indent="2"><img src="s.gif" height="1" width="80"></td><td valign="top" class="votelinks"><center><a id="up_44828964" href="vote?id=44828964&amp;how=up&amp;goto=item%3Fid%3D44826997"><div class="votearrow" title="upvote"></div></a></center></td><td class="default"><div style="margin-top:2px; margin-bottom:-10px;"><span class="comhead"><a href="user?id=rtkwe" class="hnuser">rtkwe</a> <span class="age" title="2025-08-07T19:05:44 1754593544"><a href="item?id=44828964">13 minutes ago</a></span> <span id="unv_44828964"></span><span class="navs">| <a href="#44827498" class="clicky" aria-hidden="true">root</a> | <a href="#44828122" class="clicky" aria-hidden="true">parent</a> | <a href="#44828365" class="clicky" aria-hidden="true">next</a> <a class="togg clicky" id="44828964" n="1" href="javascript:void(0)">[–]</a><span class="onstory"></span></span></span></div><br><div class="comment"><div class="commtext c00">It's going to be really hard to root out it's all over the place because it's so commonly mentioned when teaching the Bernoulli Principal to kids.</div><div class="reply"><p><font size="1"><u><a href="reply?id=44828964&amp;goto=item%3Fid%3D44826997%2344828964" rel="nofollow">reply</a></u></font></p></div></div></td></tr></tbody></table>

<table border="0"><tbody><tr><td class="ind" indent="1"><img src="s.gif" height="1" width="40"></td><td valign="top" class="votelinks"><center><a id="up_44828365" href="vote?id=44828365&amp;how=up&amp;goto=item%3Fid%3D44826997"><div class="votearrow" title="upvote"></div></a></center></td><td class="default"><div style="margin-top:2px; margin-bottom:-10px;"><span class="comhead"><a href="user?id=tim333" class="hnuser">tim333</a> <span class="age" title="2025-08-07T18:20:08 1754590808"><a href="item?id=44828365">58 minutes ago</a></span> <span id="unv_44828365"></span><span class="navs">| <a href="#44827498" class="clicky" aria-hidden="true">parent</a> | <a href="#44828122" class="clicky" aria-hidden="true">prev</a> | <a href="#44827946" class="clicky" aria-hidden="true">next</a> <a class="togg clicky" id="44828365" n="1" href="javascript:void(0)">[–]</a><span class="onstory"></span></span></span></div><br><div class="comment"><div class="commtext c00">From Wikipedia<p>&gt;In fact, theory predicts – and experiments confirm – that the air traverses the top surface of a body experiencing lift in a shorter time than it traverses the bottom surface; the explanation based on equal transit time is false.</p><p>So the effect is greater than equal time transit.</p><p>I've seen the GPT5 explanation in GCSE level textbooks but I thought it was supposed to be PhD level;)</p></div><div class="reply"><p><font size="1"><u><a href="reply?id=44828365&amp;goto=item%3Fid%3D44826997%2344828365" rel="nofollow">reply</a></u></font></p></div></div></td></tr></tbody></table>

<table border="0"><tbody><tr><td class="ind" indent="1"><img src="s.gif" height="1" width="40"></td><td valign="top" class="votelinks"><center><a id="up_44827946" href="vote?id=44827946&amp;how=up&amp;goto=item%3Fid%3D44826997"><div class="votearrow" title="upvote"></div></a></center></td><td class="default"><div style="margin-top:2px; margin-bottom:-10px;"><span class="comhead"><a href="user?id=samfriedman" class="hnuser">samfriedman</a> <span class="age" title="2025-08-07T17:54:37 1754589277"><a href="item?id=44827946">1 hour ago</a></span> <span id="unv_44827946"></span><span class="navs">| <a href="#44827498" class="clicky" aria-hidden="true">parent</a> | <a href="#44828365" class="clicky" aria-hidden="true">prev</a> | <a href="#44827968" class="clicky" aria-hidden="true">next</a> <a class="togg clicky" id="44827946" n="1" href="javascript:void(0)">[–]</a><span class="onstory"></span></span></span></div><br><div class="comment"><div class="commtext c00">The "demo" it made was pretty horrible too. I would have been impressed if it had simulated a NACA 4412 or something.</div><div class="reply"><p><font size="1"><u><a href="reply?id=44827946&amp;goto=item%3Fid%3D44826997%2344827946" rel="nofollow">reply</a></u></font></p></div></div></td></tr></tbody></table>

<table border="0"><tbody><tr><td class="ind" indent="1"><img src="s.gif" height="1" width="40"></td><td valign="top" class="votelinks"><center><a id="up_44827968" href="vote?id=44827968&amp;how=up&amp;goto=item%3Fid%3D44826997"><div class="votearrow" title="upvote"></div></a></center></td><td class="default"><div style="margin-top:2px; margin-bottom:-10px;"><span class="comhead"><a href="user?id=timr" class="hnuser">timr</a> <span class="age" title="2025-08-07T17:56:21 1754589381"><a href="item?id=44827968">1 hour ago</a></span> <span id="unv_44827968"></span><span class="navs">| <a href="#44827498" class="clicky" aria-hidden="true">parent</a> | <a href="#44827946" class="clicky" aria-hidden="true">prev</a> | <a href="#44828319" class="clicky" aria-hidden="true">next</a> <a class="togg clicky" id="44827968" n="9" href="javascript:void(0)">[–]</a><span class="onstory"></span></span></span></div><br><div class="comment"><div class="commtext c00">Your link <i>literally says</i> pressure differential is the reason, and that curvature matters:<p>&gt; “What actually causes lift is introducing a shape into the airflow, which curves the streamlines and introduces pressure changes – lower pressure on the upper surface and higher pressure on the lower surface,” clarified Babinsky, from the Department of Engineering. “This is why a flat surface like a sail is able to cause lift – here the distance on each side is the same but it is slightly curved when it is rigged and so it acts as an aerofoil. In other words, it’s the curvature that creates lift, not the distance.”</p><p>So I'd characterize this answer as "correct, but incomplete" or "correct, but simplified". It's a case where a PhD in fluid dynamics might state the explanation one way to an expert audience, but another way to a room full of children.</p></div><div class="reply"><p><font size="1"><u><a href="reply?id=44827968&amp;goto=item%3Fid%3D44826997%2344827968" rel="nofollow">reply</a></u></font></p></div></div></td></tr></tbody></table>

<table border="0"><tbody><tr><td class="ind" indent="2"><img src="s.gif" height="1" width="80"></td><td valign="top" class="votelinks"><center><a id="up_44828042" href="vote?id=44828042&amp;how=up&amp;goto=item%3Fid%3D44826997"><div class="votearrow" title="upvote"></div></a></center></td><td class="default"><div style="margin-top:2px; margin-bottom:-10px;"><span class="comhead"><a href="user?id=kybernetikos" class="hnuser">kybernetikos</a> <span class="age" title="2025-08-07T18:00:07 1754589607"><a href="item?id=44828042">1 hour ago</a></span> <span id="unv_44828042"></span><span class="navs">| <a href="#44827498" class="clicky" aria-hidden="true">root</a> | <a href="#44827968" class="clicky" aria-hidden="true">parent</a> | <a href="#44828319" class="clicky" aria-hidden="true">next</a> <a class="togg clicky" id="44828042" n="8" href="javascript:void(0)">[–]</a><span class="onstory"></span></span></span></div><br><div class="comment"><div class="commtext c00">Pressure differential is absolutely one of the main components of lift (although I believe conservation of momentum is another - the coanda effect changes the direction of the airflows and there's 2nd law stuff happening on the bottom edge too), but the idea that the pressure differential is caused by the fact that "air over the top has to travel farther in the same amount of time" because the airfoil is curved is completely incorrect, as the video in my link shows.</div><div class="reply"><p><font size="1"><u><a href="reply?id=44828042&amp;goto=item%3Fid%3D44826997%2344828042" rel="nofollow">reply</a></u></font></p></div></div></td></tr></tbody></table>

<table border="0"><tbody><tr><td class="ind" indent="3"><img src="s.gif" height="1" width="120"></td><td valign="top" class="votelinks"><center><a id="up_44828144" href="vote?id=44828144&amp;how=up&amp;goto=item%3Fid%3D44826997"><div class="votearrow" title="upvote"></div></a></center></td><td class="default"><div style="margin-top:2px; margin-bottom:-10px;"><span class="comhead"><a href="user?id=timr" class="hnuser">timr</a> <span class="age" title="2025-08-07T18:05:54 1754589954"><a href="item?id=44828144">1 hour ago</a></span> <span id="unv_44828144"></span><span class="navs">| <a href="#44827498" class="clicky" aria-hidden="true">root</a> | <a href="#44828042" class="clicky" aria-hidden="true">parent</a> | <a href="#44828319" class="clicky" aria-hidden="true">next</a> <a class="togg clicky" id="44828144" n="7" href="javascript:void(0)">[–]</a><span class="onstory"></span></span></span></div><br><div class="comment"><div class="commtext c00">It's "completely incorrect" only if you're being pedantic. It's "partially correct" if you're talking casually to a group of regular people. It's "good enough" if you're talking to a classroom of children. Audience matters.<p>The hilarious thing about this subthread is that it's already getting filled with hyper-technical but wrong alternative explanations by people eager to show that they know more than the robot.</p></div><div class="reply"><p><font size="1"><u><a href="reply?id=44828144&amp;goto=item%3Fid%3D44826997%2344828144" rel="nofollow">reply</a></u></font></p></div></div></td></tr></tbody></table>

<table border="0"><tbody><tr><td class="ind" indent="4"><img src="s.gif" height="1" width="160"></td><td valign="top" class="votelinks"><center><a id="up_44829084" href="vote?id=44829084&amp;how=up&amp;goto=item%3Fid%3D44826997"><div class="votearrow" title="upvote"></div></a></center></td><td class="default"><div style="margin-top:2px; margin-bottom:-10px;"><span class="comhead"><a href="user?id=cmiles74" class="hnuser">cmiles74</a> <span class="age" title="2025-08-07T19:16:14 1754594174"><a href="item?id=44829084">2 minutes ago</a></span> <span id="unv_44829084"></span><span class="navs">| <a href="#44827498" class="clicky" aria-hidden="true">root</a> | <a href="#44828144" class="clicky" aria-hidden="true">parent</a> | <a href="#44828272" class="clicky" aria-hidden="true">next</a> <a class="togg clicky" id="44829084" n="1" href="javascript:void(0)">[–]</a><span class="onstory"></span></span></span></div><br><div class="comment"><div class="commtext c00">This is an LLM advertised as functioning at a "doctorate" level in everything. I think it's reasonable to expect more than the high school classroom "good enough" explanation.</div><div class="reply"><p><font size="1"></font></p></div></div></td></tr></tbody></table>

<table border="0"><tbody><tr><td class="ind" indent="4"><img src="s.gif" height="1" width="160"></td><td valign="top" class="votelinks"><center><a id="up_44828272" href="vote?id=44828272&amp;how=up&amp;goto=item%3Fid%3D44826997"><div class="votearrow" title="upvote"></div></a></center></td><td class="default"><div style="margin-top:2px; margin-bottom:-10px;"><span class="comhead"><a href="user?id=kybernetikos" class="hnuser">kybernetikos</a> <span class="age" title="2025-08-07T18:13:50 1754590430"><a href="item?id=44828272">1 hour ago</a></span> <span id="unv_44828272"></span><span class="navs">| <a href="#44827498" class="clicky" aria-hidden="true">root</a> | <a href="#44828144" class="clicky" aria-hidden="true">parent</a> | <a href="#44829084" class="clicky" aria-hidden="true">prev</a> | <a href="#44828301" class="clicky" aria-hidden="true">next</a> <a class="togg clicky" id="44828272" n="4" href="javascript:void(0)">[–]</a><span class="onstory"></span></span></span></div><br><div class="comment"><div class="commtext c00">"air over the top has to travel farther in the same amount of time" is just wrong, it doesn't have to, and in fact it doesn't.<p>It's called the "equal transit-time fallacy" if you want to look it up, or follow the link I provided in my comment, or perhaps the NASA link someone else offered.</p></div><div class="reply"><p><font size="1"><u><a href="reply?id=44828272&amp;goto=item%3Fid%3D44826997%2344828272" rel="nofollow">reply</a></u></font></p></div></div></td></tr></tbody></table>

<table border="0"><tbody><tr><td class="ind" indent="5"><img src="s.gif" height="1" width="200"></td><td valign="top" class="votelinks"><center><a id="up_44828330" href="vote?id=44828330&amp;how=up&amp;goto=item%3Fid%3D44826997"><div class="votearrow" title="upvote"></div></a></center></td><td class="default"><div style="margin-top:2px; margin-bottom:-10px;"><span class="comhead"><a href="user?id=timr" class="hnuser">timr</a> <span class="age" title="2025-08-07T18:17:18 1754590638"><a href="item?id=44828330">1 hour ago</a></span> <span id="unv_44828330"></span><span class="navs">| <a href="#44827498" class="clicky" aria-hidden="true">root</a> | <a href="#44828272" class="clicky" aria-hidden="true">parent</a> | <a href="#44828301" class="clicky" aria-hidden="true">next</a> <a class="togg clicky" id="44828330" n="3" href="javascript:void(0)">[–]</a><span class="onstory"></span></span></span></div><br><div class="comment"><div class="commtext c00">I'm not saying that particular point is wrong. I'm saying that for most people, it doesn't matter, and the reason the "fallacy" persists is because it's a good enough explanation for the layman that is easy to conceptualize.<p>Pretty much any scientific question is fractal like this: there's a superficial explanation, then one below that, and so on. None are "completely incorrect", but the more detailed ones are better.</p><p>The real question is: if you prompt the bot for the better, deeper explanation, what does it do?</p></div><div class="reply"><p><font size="1"><u><a href="reply?id=44828330&amp;goto=item%3Fid%3D44826997%2344828330" rel="nofollow">reply</a></u></font></p></div></div></td></tr></tbody></table>

<table border="0"><tbody><tr><td class="ind" indent="6"><img src="s.gif" height="1" width="240"></td><td valign="top" class="votelinks"><center><a id="up_44828596" href="vote?id=44828596&amp;how=up&amp;goto=item%3Fid%3D44826997"><div class="votearrow" title="upvote"></div></a></center></td><td class="default"><div style="margin-top:2px; margin-bottom:-10px;"><span class="comhead"><a href="user?id=kybernetikos" class="hnuser">kybernetikos</a> <span class="age" title="2025-08-07T18:36:15 1754591775"><a href="item?id=44828596">42 minutes ago</a></span> <span id="unv_44828596"></span><span class="navs">| <a href="#44827498" class="clicky" aria-hidden="true">root</a> | <a href="#44828330" class="clicky" aria-hidden="true">parent</a> | <a href="#44828301" class="clicky" aria-hidden="true">next</a> <a class="togg clicky" id="44828596" n="2" href="javascript:void(0)">[–]</a><span class="onstory"></span></span></span></div><br><div class="comment"><div class="commtext c00">So I worry that you think that the equal transit time thing is true, but is just one effect among others. This is not the case. There <i>are</i> a number of different effects, including bernoulli and coanda and newtons third law that all contribute to lift, but none of the things that actually happen have anything to do with equal transit time.<p>The equal transit time is not a partially correct explanation, it's something that doesn't happen. It's not a superficial explanation, it's a <i>wrong</i> explanation. It's not even a good lie-to-children, as it doesn't help predict or understand any part of the system at any level. It instead teaches magical thinking.</p><p>As to whether it matters? If I am told that I can ask my question to a system and it will respond like a team of PhDs, that it is useful to help someone with their homework and physical understanding, but it gives me instead information that is incorrect and misleading, I would say the system is not working as it is intended to.</p><p>Even if I accept that "audience matters" as you say, the suggested audience is helping someone with their physics homework. This would not be a suitable explanation for someone doing physics homework.</p></div><div class="reply"><p><font size="1"><u><a href="reply?id=44828596&amp;goto=item%3Fid%3D44826997%2344828596" rel="nofollow">reply</a></u></font></p></div></div></td></tr></tbody></table>

<table border="0"><tbody><tr><td class="ind" indent="7"><img src="s.gif" height="1" width="280"></td><td valign="top" class="votelinks"><center><a id="up_44828782" href="vote?id=44828782&amp;how=up&amp;goto=item%3Fid%3D44826997"><div class="votearrow" title="upvote"></div></a></center></td><td class="default"><div style="margin-top:2px; margin-bottom:-10px;"><span class="comhead"><a href="user?id=timr" class="hnuser">timr</a> <span class="age" title="2025-08-07T18:50:47 1754592647"><a href="item?id=44828782">27 minutes ago</a></span> <span id="unv_44828782"></span><span class="navs">| <a href="#44827498" class="clicky" aria-hidden="true">root</a> | <a href="#44828596" class="clicky" aria-hidden="true">parent</a> | <a href="#44828301" class="clicky" aria-hidden="true">next</a> <a class="togg clicky" id="44828782" n="1" href="javascript:void(0)">[–]</a><span class="onstory"></span></span></span></div><br><div class="comment"><div class="commtext c00">&gt; So I worry that you think that the equal transit time thing is true,<p>Wow. Thanks for your worry, but it's not a problem. I do understand the difference, and yet it doesn't have anything to do with the argument I'm making, which is about <i>presentation.</i></p><p>&gt; It's not even a good lie-to-children, as it doesn't help predict or understand any part of the system at any level.</p><p>...which is irrelevant in the context. I get the meta-point that you're (sort of) making that you can't shut your brain off and just hope the bot spits out 100% pedantic explanations of scientific phenomenon. That's true, but also...fine?</p><p>These things are spitting out probable text. If (as many have observed) this is a common enough explanation to be in <i>textbooks</i>, then I'm not particularly surprised if an LLM emits it as well. The real question is: what happens when you prompt it to go deeper?</p></div><div class="reply"><p><font size="1"><u><a href="reply?id=44828782&amp;goto=item%3Fid%3D44826997%2344828782" rel="nofollow">reply</a></u></font></p></div></div></td></tr></tbody></table>

<table border="0"><tbody><tr><td class="ind" indent="4"><img src="s.gif" height="1" width="160"></td><td valign="top" class="votelinks"><center><a id="up_44828301" href="vote?id=44828301&amp;how=up&amp;goto=item%3Fid%3D44826997"><div class="votearrow" title="upvote"></div></a></center></td><td class="default"><div style="margin-top:2px; margin-bottom:-10px;"><span class="comhead"><a href="user?id=bccdee" class="hnuser">bccdee</a> <span class="age" title="2025-08-07T18:15:38 1754590538"><a href="item?id=44828301">1 hour ago</a></span> <span id="unv_44828301"></span><span class="navs">| <a href="#44827498" class="clicky" aria-hidden="true">root</a> | <a href="#44828144" class="clicky" aria-hidden="true">parent</a> | <a href="#44828272" class="clicky" aria-hidden="true">prev</a> | <a href="#44828319" class="clicky" aria-hidden="true">next</a> <a class="togg clicky" id="44828301" n="1" href="javascript:void(0)">[–]</a><span class="onstory"></span></span></span></div><br><div class="comment"><div class="commtext c00">No, it's never good enough, because it's flat-out wrong. This statement:<p>&gt; Air over the top has to travel farther in the same amount of time</p><p>is not true. The air on top does not travel farther in the same amount of time. The air slows down and travels a shorter distance in the same amount of time.</p><p>It's only "good enough for a classroom of children" in the same way that storks delivering babies is—i.e., if you're content to simply lie rather than bothering to tell the truth.</p></div><div class="reply"><p><font size="1"><u><a href="reply?id=44828301&amp;goto=item%3Fid%3D44826997%2344828301" rel="nofollow">reply</a></u></font></p></div></div></td></tr></tbody></table>

<table border="0"><tbody><tr><td class="ind" indent="1"><img src="s.gif" height="1" width="40"></td><td valign="top" class="votelinks"><center><a id="up_44828319" href="vote?id=44828319&amp;how=up&amp;goto=item%3Fid%3D44826997"><div class="votearrow" title="upvote"></div></a></center></td><td class="default"><div style="margin-top:2px; margin-bottom:-10px;"><span class="comhead"><a href="user?id=ttoinou" class="hnuser">ttoinou</a> <span class="age" title="2025-08-07T18:16:54 1754590614"><a href="item?id=44828319">1 hour ago</a></span> <span id="unv_44828319"></span><span class="navs">| <a href="#44827498" class="clicky" aria-hidden="true">parent</a> | <a href="#44827968" class="clicky" aria-hidden="true">prev</a> | <a href="#44828156" class="clicky" aria-hidden="true">next</a> <a class="togg clicky" id="44828319" n="1" href="javascript:void(0)">[–]</a><span class="onstory"></span></span></span></div><br><div class="comment"><div class="commtext c00">Its not fully wrong but its a typical example of how simplified scientific explanations have spread everywhere without personal verification of each person involved in the chinese whisper</div><div class="reply"><p><font size="1"><u><a href="reply?id=44828319&amp;goto=item%3Fid%3D44826997%2344828319" rel="nofollow">reply</a></u></font></p></div></div></td></tr></tbody></table>

<table border="0"><tbody><tr><td class="ind" indent="1"><img src="s.gif" height="1" width="40"></td><td valign="top" class="votelinks"><center><a id="up_44828156" href="vote?id=44828156&amp;how=up&amp;goto=item%3Fid%3D44826997"><div class="votearrow" title="upvote"></div></a></center></td><td class="default"><div style="margin-top:2px; margin-bottom:-10px;"><span class="comhead"><a href="user?id=IanCal" class="hnuser">IanCal</a> <span class="age" title="2025-08-07T18:06:42 1754590002"><a href="item?id=44828156">1 hour ago</a></span> <span id="unv_44828156"></span><span class="navs">| <a href="#44827498" class="clicky" aria-hidden="true">parent</a> | <a href="#44828319" class="clicky" aria-hidden="true">prev</a> | <a href="#44828392" class="clicky" aria-hidden="true">next</a> <a class="togg clicky" id="44828156" n="1" href="javascript:void(0)">[–]</a><span class="onstory"></span></span></span></div><br><div class="comment"><div class="commtext c00">As a complete aside I’ve always hated that explanation where air moves up and over a bump, the lines get closer together and then the explanation is the pressure <i>lowers</i> at that point. Also the idea that the lines of air look the same before and after and yet somehow the wing should have moved up.</div><div class="reply"><p><font size="1"><u><a href="reply?id=44828156&amp;goto=item%3Fid%3D44826997%2344828156" rel="nofollow">reply</a></u></font></p></div></div></td></tr></tbody></table>

<table border="0"><tbody><tr><td class="ind" indent="1"><img src="s.gif" height="1" width="40"></td><td valign="top" class="votelinks"><center><a id="up_44828392" href="vote?id=44828392&amp;how=up&amp;goto=item%3Fid%3D44826997"><div class="votearrow" title="upvote"></div></a></center></td><td class="default"><div style="margin-top:2px; margin-bottom:-10px;"><span class="comhead"><a href="user?id=karel-3d" class="hnuser">karel-3d</a> <span class="age" title="2025-08-07T18:21:52 1754590912"><a href="item?id=44828392">56 minutes ago</a></span> <span id="unv_44828392"></span><span class="navs">| <a href="#44827498" class="clicky" aria-hidden="true">parent</a> | <a href="#44828156" class="clicky" aria-hidden="true">prev</a> | <a href="#44828292" class="clicky" aria-hidden="true">next</a> <a class="togg clicky" id="44828392" n="1" href="javascript:void(0)">[–]</a><span class="onstory"></span></span></span></div><br><div class="comment"><div class="commtext c00">yeah that's a great thing to use as LLM demo because it sounds plausible yet it's completely misleading and wrong.</div><div class="reply"><p><font size="1"><u><a href="reply?id=44828392&amp;goto=item%3Fid%3D44826997%2344828392" rel="nofollow">reply</a></u></font></p></div></div></td></tr></tbody></table>

<table border="0"><tbody><tr><td class="ind" indent="1"><img src="s.gif" height="1" width="40"></td><td valign="top" class="votelinks"><center><a id="up_44828292" href="vote?id=44828292&amp;how=up&amp;goto=item%3Fid%3D44826997"><div class="votearrow" title="upvote"></div></a></center></td><td class="default"><div style="margin-top:2px; margin-bottom:-10px;"><span class="comhead"><a href="user?id=croes" class="hnuser">croes</a> <span class="age" title="2025-08-07T18:15:04 1754590504"><a href="item?id=44828292">1 hour ago</a></span> <span id="unv_44828292"></span><span class="navs">| <a href="#44827498" class="clicky" aria-hidden="true">parent</a> | <a href="#44828392" class="clicky" aria-hidden="true">prev</a> | <a href="#44827683" class="clicky" aria-hidden="true">next</a> <a class="togg clicky" id="44828292" n="1" href="javascript:void(0)">[–]</a><span class="onstory"></span></span></span></div><br><div class="comment"><div class="commtext c00">It’s a common misconception, I doubt they know themselves and GPT 5 doesn’t tell them otherwise because it’s the mist common in explanation in the training data.<p>A quite good example of AI limits</p></div><div class="reply"><p><font size="1"><u><a href="reply?id=44828292&amp;goto=item%3Fid%3D44826997%2344828292" rel="nofollow">reply</a></u></font></p></div></div></td></tr></tbody></table>

<table border="0"><tbody><tr><td class="ind" indent="1"><img src="s.gif" height="1" width="40"></td><td valign="top" class="votelinks"><center><a id="up_44827683" href="vote?id=44827683&amp;how=up&amp;goto=item%3Fid%3D44826997"><div class="votearrow" title="upvote"></div></a></center></td><td class="default"><div style="margin-top:2px; margin-bottom:-10px;"><span class="comhead"><a href="user?id=AnimalMuppet" class="hnuser">AnimalMuppet</a> <span class="age" title="2025-08-07T17:40:38 1754588438"><a href="item?id=44827683">1 hour ago</a></span> <span id="unv_44827683"></span><span class="navs">| <a href="#44827498" class="clicky" aria-hidden="true">parent</a> | <a href="#44828292" class="clicky" aria-hidden="true">prev</a> | <a href="#44828171" class="clicky" aria-hidden="true">next</a> <a class="togg clicky" id="44827683" n="7" href="javascript:void(0)">[–]</a><span class="onstory"></span></span></span></div><br><div class="comment"><div class="commtext c00">Yes. But I strongly suspect that it's the most <i>frequent</i> answer in the training data...</div><div class="reply"><p><font size="1"><u><a href="reply?id=44827683&amp;goto=item%3Fid%3D44826997%2344827683" rel="nofollow">reply</a></u></font></p></div></div></td></tr></tbody></table>

<table border="0"><tbody><tr><td class="ind" indent="2"><img src="s.gif" height="1" width="80"></td><td valign="top" class="votelinks"><center><a id="up_44828226" href="vote?id=44828226&amp;how=up&amp;goto=item%3Fid%3D44826997"><div class="votearrow" title="upvote"></div></a></center></td><td class="default"><div style="margin-top:2px; margin-bottom:-10px;"><span class="comhead"><a href="user?id=bambax" class="hnuser">bambax</a> <span class="age" title="2025-08-07T18:11:20 1754590280"><a href="item?id=44828226">1 hour ago</a></span> <span id="unv_44828226"></span><span class="navs">| <a href="#44827498" class="clicky" aria-hidden="true">root</a> | <a href="#44827683" class="clicky" aria-hidden="true">parent</a> | <a href="#44827933" class="clicky" aria-hidden="true">next</a> <a class="togg clicky" id="44828226" n="2" href="javascript:void(0)">[–]</a><span class="onstory"></span></span></span></div><br><div class="comment"><div class="commtext c00">They couldn't find a more apt demnonstration of what an LLM is and does if they tried.<p>An LLM doesn't know more than what's in the training data.</p><p>In Michael Crichton's The Great Train Robbery (published in 1975, about events that happened in 1855) the perpetrator, having been caught, explains to a baffled court that he was able to walk on top of a running train "because of the Bernoulli effect", that he misspells and completely misunderstands. I don't remember if this argument helps him get away with the crime? Maybe it does, I'm not sure.</p><p>This is another attempt at a Great Robbery.</p></div><div class="reply"><p><font size="1"><u><a href="reply?id=44828226&amp;goto=item%3Fid%3D44826997%2344828226" rel="nofollow">reply</a></u></font></p></div></div></td></tr></tbody></table>

<table border="0"><tbody><tr><td class="ind" indent="3"><img src="s.gif" height="1" width="120"></td><td valign="top" class="votelinks"><center><a id="up_44829019" href="vote?id=44829019&amp;how=up&amp;goto=item%3Fid%3D44826997"><div class="votearrow" title="upvote"></div></a></center></td><td class="default"><div style="margin-top:2px; margin-bottom:-10px;"><span class="comhead"><a href="user?id=gowld" class="hnuser">gowld</a> <span class="age" title="2025-08-07T19:09:46 1754593786"><a href="item?id=44829019">8 minutes ago</a></span> <span id="unv_44829019"></span><span class="navs">| <a href="#44827498" class="clicky" aria-hidden="true">root</a> | <a href="#44828226" class="clicky" aria-hidden="true">parent</a> | <a href="#44827933" class="clicky" aria-hidden="true">next</a> <a class="togg clicky" id="44829019" n="1" href="javascript:void(0)">[–]</a><span class="onstory"></span></span></span></div><br><div class="comment"><div class="commtext c00">For those who want to read about the "Baroni" effect in the book: <a href="https://bookreadfree.com/361033/8879470" rel="nofollow">https://bookreadfree.com/361033/8879470</a><p>It goes on:</p><p>&gt; At this point, the prosecutor asked for further elucidation, which Pierce gave in garbled form. The summary of this portion of the trial, as reported in the Times, was garbled still further. The general idea was that Pierce--- by now almost revered in the press as a master criminal--- possessed some knowledge of a scientific principle that had aided him.</p><p>How apropos to modern science reporting and LLMs.</p></div><div class="reply"><p><font size="1"><u><a href="reply?id=44829019&amp;goto=item%3Fid%3D44826997%2344829019" rel="nofollow">reply</a></u></font></p></div></div></td></tr></tbody></table>

<table border="0"><tbody><tr><td class="ind" indent="2"><img src="s.gif" height="1" width="80"></td><td valign="top" class="votelinks"><center><a id="up_44827933" href="vote?id=44827933&amp;how=up&amp;goto=item%3Fid%3D44826997"><div class="votearrow" title="upvote"></div></a></center></td><td class="default"><div style="margin-top:2px; margin-bottom:-10px;"><span class="comhead"><a href="user?id=NelsonMinar" class="hnuser">NelsonMinar</a> <span class="age" title="2025-08-07T17:53:44 1754589224"><a href="item?id=44827933">1 hour ago</a></span> <span id="unv_44827933"></span><span class="navs">| <a href="#44827498" class="clicky" aria-hidden="true">root</a> | <a href="#44827683" class="clicky" aria-hidden="true">parent</a> | <a href="#44828226" class="clicky" aria-hidden="true">prev</a> | <a href="#44828051" class="clicky" aria-hidden="true">next</a> <a class="togg clicky" id="44827933" n="3" href="javascript:void(0)">[–]</a><span class="onstory"></span></span></span></div><br><div class="comment"><div class="commtext c00">IIRC I was required to regurgitate this wrong answer to pass my FAA pilot exam.</div><div class="reply"><p><font size="1"><u><a href="reply?id=44827933&amp;goto=item%3Fid%3D44826997%2344827933" rel="nofollow">reply</a></u></font></p></div></div></td></tr></tbody></table>

<table border="0"><tbody><tr><td class="ind" indent="3"><img src="s.gif" height="1" width="120"></td><td valign="top" class="votelinks"><center><a id="up_44828638" href="vote?id=44828638&amp;how=up&amp;goto=item%3Fid%3D44826997"><div class="votearrow" title="upvote"></div></a></center></td><td class="default"><div style="margin-top:2px; margin-bottom:-10px;"><span class="comhead"><a href="user?id=carabiner" class="hnuser">carabiner</a> <span class="age" title="2025-08-07T18:39:31 1754591971"><a href="item?id=44828638">39 minutes ago</a></span> <span id="unv_44828638"></span><span class="navs">| <a href="#44827498" class="clicky" aria-hidden="true">root</a> | <a href="#44827933" class="clicky" aria-hidden="true">parent</a> | <a href="#44827958" class="clicky" aria-hidden="true">next</a> <a class="togg clicky" id="44828638" n="1" href="javascript:void(0)">[–]</a><span class="onstory"></span></span></span></div><br><div class="comment"><div class="commtext c00">Yeah, it's like asking a car driver (even a professional driver) to explain the Otto cycle. <table border="0"><tbody><tr><td class="ind" indent="3"><img src="s.gif" height="1" width="120"></td><td valign="top" class="votelinks"><center><a id="up_44827958" href="vote?id=44827958&amp;how=up&amp;goto=item%3Fid%3D44826997"><div class="votearrow" title="upvote"></div></a></center></td><td class="default"><div style="margin-top:2px; margin-bottom:-10px;"><span class="comhead"><a href="user?id=CPLX" class="hnuser">CPLX</a> <span class="age" title="2025-08-07T17:55:40 1754589340"><a href="item?id=44827958">1 hour ago</a></span> <span id="unv_44827958"></span><span class="navs">| <a href="#44827498" class="clicky" aria-hidden="true">root</a> | <a href="#44827933" class="clicky" aria-hidden="true">parent</a> | <a href="#44828638" class="clicky" aria-hidden="true">prev</a> | <a href="#44828051" class="clicky" aria-hidden="true">next</a> <a class="togg clicky" id="44827958" n="1" href="javascript:void(0)">[–]</a><span class="onstory"></span></span></span></div><br><div class="comment"><div class="commtext c00">Yeah me too, so it's found in many authoritative places.<p>And I might be wrong but my understanding is that it's not <i>wrong</i> per-se, it's just wildly incomplete. <table border="0"><tbody><tr><td class="ind" indent="2"><img src="s.gif" height="1" width="80"></td><td valign="top" class="votelinks"><center><a id="up_44828051" href="vote?id=44828051&amp;how=up&amp;goto=item%3Fid%3D44826997"><div class="votearrow" title="upvote"></div></a></center></td><td class="default"><div style="margin-top:2px; margin-bottom:-10px;"><span class="comhead"><a href="user?id=gekoxyz" class="hnuser">gekoxyz</a> <span class="age" title="2025-08-07T18:00:39 1754589639"><a href="item?id=44828051">1 hour ago</a></span> <span id="unv_44828051"></span><span class="navs">| <a href="#44827498" class="clicky" aria-hidden="true">root</a> | <a href="#44827683" class="clicky" aria-hidden="true">parent</a> | <a href="#44827933" class="clicky" aria-hidden="true">prev</a> | <a href="#44828171" class="clicky" aria-hidden="true">next</a> <a class="togg clicky" id="44828051" n="1" href="javascript:void(0)">[–]</a><span class="onstory"></span></span></span></div><br><div class="comment"><div class="commtext c00">And your suspicion is right. The sad reality is that it's just a stochastic parrot, that can produce really good answers in certain occasions.</div><div class="reply"><p><font size="1"><u><a href="reply?id=44828051&amp;goto=item%3Fid%3D44826997%2344828051" rel="nofollow">reply</a></u></font></p></div></div></td></tr></tbody></table>

<table border="0"><tbody><tr><td class="ind" indent="1"><img src="s.gif" height="1" width="40"></td><td valign="top" class="votelinks"><center><a id="up_44828523" href="vote?id=44828523&amp;how=up&amp;goto=item%3Fid%3D44826997"><div class="votearrow" title="upvote"></div></a></center></td><td class="default"><div style="margin-top:2px; margin-bottom:-10px;"><span class="comhead"><a href="user?id=avs733" class="hnuser">avs733</a> <span class="age" title="2025-08-07T18:31:45 1754591505"><a href="item?id=44828523">46 minutes ago</a></span> <span id="unv_44828523"></span><span class="navs">| <a href="#44827498" class="clicky" aria-hidden="true">parent</a> | <a href="#44827890" class="clicky" aria-hidden="true">prev</a> | <a href="#44828040" class="clicky" aria-hidden="true">next</a> <a class="togg clicky" id="44828523" n="1" href="javascript:void(0)">[–]</a><span class="onstory"></span></span></span></div><br><div class="comment"><div class="commtext c00">Its a particular type of mistake that is really interesting and telling. It is a misconception - and a common socially disseminated simplifcation. In students, these don't come from a lack of knowledge but rather from places where knowledge is structured incorrectly. Often because the phenomenon are difficult to observe or mislead when observed. Another example is heat and temperature. Heat is not temperature, but it is easy to observe them always being the same in your day to day life and so you bring that belief into a college thermodynamics course where you are learning that heat and temperature are different for the first time. It is a commonsense observation of the world that is only incorrect in technical circles<p>These are places where common lay discussions use language in ways that is wrong, or makes simplifcations that are reasonable but technically incorrect. They are especially common when something is so 'obvious' that experts don't explain it, the most frequent version of the concepts being explained</p><p>These, in my testing, show up a lot in LLMs - technical things are wrong when the most language of the most common explanations simplifies or obfuscates the precise truth. Often, it pretty much matches the level of knowledge of a college freshman/sophmore or slightly below, which is sort of the level of discussion of more technical topics on the internet.</p></div><div class="reply"><p><font size="1"><u><a href="reply?id=44828523&amp;goto=item%3Fid%3D44826997%2344828523" rel="nofollow">reply</a></u></font></p></div></div></td></tr></tbody></table>

<table border="0"><tbody><tr><td class="ind" indent="0"><img src="s.gif" height="1" width="0"></td><td valign="top" class="votelinks"><center><a id="up_44827878" href="vote?id=44827878&amp;how=up&amp;goto=item%3Fid%3D44826997"><div class="votearrow" title="upvote"></div></a></center></td><td class="default"><div style="margin-top:2px; margin-bottom:-10px;"><span class="comhead"><a href="user?id=Topfi" class="hnuser">Topfi</a> <span class="age" title="2025-08-07T17:51:02 1754589062"><a href="item?id=44827878">1 hour ago</a></span> <span id="unv_44827878"></span><span class="navs">| <a href="#44827304" class="clicky" aria-hidden="true">prev</a> | <a href="#44827442" class="clicky" aria-hidden="true">next</a> <a class="togg clicky" id="44827878" n="4" href="javascript:void(0)">[–]</a><span class="onstory"></span></span></span></div><br><div class="comment"><div class="commtext c00">&gt; 400,000 context window<p>&gt; 128,000 max output tokens</p><p>&gt; Input $1.25</p><p>&gt; Output $10.00</p><p>Source: <a href="https://platform.openai.com/docs/models/gpt-5" rel="nofollow">https://platform.openai.com/docs/models/gpt-5</a></p><p>If this performs well in independent needle-in-haystack and adherence evaluations, this pricing with this context window alone would make GPT-5 extremely competitive with Gemini 2.5 Pro and Claude Opus 4.1, even if the output isn't a significant improvement over o3. <table border="0"><tbody><tr><td class="ind" indent="1"><img src="s.gif" height="1" width="40"></td><td valign="top" class="votelinks"><center><a id="up_44828672" href="vote?id=44828672&amp;how=up&amp;goto=item%3Fid%3D44826997"><div class="votearrow" title="upvote"></div></a></center></td><td class="default"><div style="margin-top:2px; margin-bottom:-10px;"><span class="comhead"><a href="user?id=iammrpayments" class="hnuser">iammrpayments</a> <span class="age" title="2025-08-07T18:41:30 1754592090"><a href="item?id=44828672">37 minutes ago</a></span> <span id="unv_44828672"></span><span class="navs">| <a href="#44827878" class="clicky" aria-hidden="true">parent</a> | <a href="#44828221" class="clicky" aria-hidden="true">prev</a> | <a href="#44827442" class="clicky" aria-hidden="true">next</a> <a class="togg clicky" id="44828672" n="2" href="javascript:void(0)">[–]</a><span class="onstory"></span></span></span></div><br><div class="comment"><div class="commtext c00">You also have to count the cost of having to verify your identity to use the API</div><div class="reply"><p><font size="1"><u><a href="reply?id=44828672&amp;goto=item%3Fid%3D44826997%2344828672" rel="nofollow">reply</a></u></font></p></div></div></td></tr></tbody></table>

<table border="0"><tbody><tr><td class="ind" indent="0"><img src="s.gif" height="1" width="0"></td><td valign="top" class="votelinks"><center><a id="up_44827442" href="vote?id=44827442&amp;how=up&amp;goto=item%3Fid%3D44826997"><div class="votearrow" title="upvote"></div></a></center></td><td class="default"><div style="margin-top:2px; margin-bottom:-10px;"><span class="comhead"><a href="user?id=jumploops" class="hnuser">jumploops</a> <span class="age" title="2025-08-07T17:25:27 1754587527"><a href="item?id=44827442">1 hour ago</a></span> <span id="unv_44827442"></span><span class="navs">| <a href="#44827878" class="clicky" aria-hidden="true">prev</a> | <a href="#44827265" class="clicky" aria-hidden="true">next</a> <a class="togg clicky" id="44827442" n="3" href="javascript:void(0)">[–]</a><span class="onstory"></span></span></span></div><br><div class="comment"><div class="commtext c00">Pricing seems good, but the open question is still on tool calling reliability.<p>Input: $1.25 / 1M tokens Cached: $0.125 / 1M tokens Output: $10 / 1M tokens</p><p>With 74.9% on SWE-bench, this inches out Claude Opus 4.1 at 74.5%, but at a much cheaper cost.</p><p>For context, Claude Opus 4.1 is $15 / 1M input tokens and $75 / 1M output tokens.</p><p>&gt; "GPT-5 will scaffold the app, write files, install dependencies as needed, and show a live preview. This is the go-to solution for developers who want to bootstrap apps or add features quickly." [0]</p><p>Since Claude Code launched, OpenAI has been behind. Maybe the RL on tool calling is good enough to be competitive now?</p><p>[0]<a href="https://github.com/openai/gpt-5-coding-examples" rel="nofollow">https://github.com/openai/gpt-5-coding-examples</a></p></div><div class="reply"><p><font size="1"><u><a href="reply?id=44827442&amp;goto=item%3Fid%3D44826997%2344827442" rel="nofollow">reply</a></u></font></p></div></div></td></tr></tbody></table>

<table border="0"><tbody><tr><td class="ind" indent="0"><img src="s.gif" height="1" width="0"></td><td valign="top" class="votelinks"><center><a id="up_44828159" href="vote?id=44828159&amp;how=up&amp;goto=item%3Fid%3D44826997"><div class="votearrow" title="upvote"></div></a></center></td><td class="default"><div style="margin-top:2px; margin-bottom:-10px;"><span class="comhead"><a href="user?id=hrpnk" class="hnuser">hrpnk</a> <span class="age" title="2025-08-07T18:06:55 1754590015"><a href="item?id=44828159">1 hour ago</a></span> <span id="unv_44828159"></span><span class="navs">| <a href="#44827265" class="clicky" aria-hidden="true">prev</a> | <a href="#44827450" class="clicky" aria-hidden="true">next</a> <a class="togg clicky" id="44828159" n="3" href="javascript:void(0)">[–]</a><span class="onstory"></span></span></span></div><br><div class="comment"><div class="commtext c00">They will retire lots of models: GPT-4o, GPT-4.1, GPT-4.5, GPT-4.1-mini, o4-mini, o4-mini-high, o3, o3-pro.<p><a href="https://help.openai.com/en/articles/6825453-chatgpt-release-notes" rel="nofollow">https://help.openai.com/en/articles/6825453-chatgpt-release-...</a></p><p>"If you open a conversation that used one of these models, ChatGPT will automatically switch it to the closest GPT-5 equivalent."</p><p>- 4o, 4.1, 4.5, 4.1-mini, o4-mini, or o4-mini-high =&gt; GPT-5 - o3 =&gt; GPT-5-Thinking - o3-Pro =&gt; GPT-5-Pro</p></div><div class="reply"><p><font size="1"><u><a href="reply?id=44828159&amp;goto=item%3Fid%3D44826997%2344828159" rel="nofollow">reply</a></u></font></p></div></div></td></tr></tbody></table>

Do you know researchers actively on the cusp or are you just going off vibes?</div><div class="reply"><p><font size="1"><u><a href="reply?id=44828847&amp;goto=item%3Fid%3D44826997%2344828847" rel="nofollow">reply</a></u></font></p></div></div></td></tr></tbody></table>

<table border="0"><tbody><tr><td class="ind" indent="0"><img src="s.gif" height="1" width="0"></td><td valign="top" class="votelinks"><center><a id="up_44828079" href="vote?id=44828079&amp;how=up&amp;goto=item%3Fid%3D44826997"><div class="votearrow" title="upvote"></div></a></center></td><td class="default"><div style="margin-top:2px; margin-bottom:-10px;"><span class="comhead"><a href="user?id=sundarurfriend" class="hnuser">sundarurfriend</a> <span class="age" title="2025-08-07T18:02:22 1754589742"><a href="item?id=44828079">1 hour ago</a></span> <span id="unv_44828079"></span><span class="navs">| <a href="#44827450" class="clicky" aria-hidden="true">prev</a> | <a href="#44826563" class="clicky" aria-hidden="true">next</a> <a class="togg clicky" id="44828079" n="1" href="javascript:void(0)">[–]</a><span class="onstory"></span></span></span></div><br><div class="comment"><div class="commtext c00">Some people have hypothesized that GPT-5 is actually about cost reduction and internal optimization for OpenAI, since there doesn't seem to be much of a leap forward, but another element that they seem to have focused on that'll probably make a huge difference to "normal" (non-tech) users is making precise and specifically worded prompts less necessary.<p>They've mentioned improvements in that aspects a few times now, and if it actually materializes, that would be a big leap forward for most users even if underneath GPT-4 was also technically able to do the same things if prompted just the right way.</p></div><div class="reply"><p><font size="1"><u><a href="reply?id=44828079&amp;goto=item%3Fid%3D44826997%2344828079" rel="nofollow">reply</a></u></font></p></div></div></td></tr></tbody></table>

<table border="0"><tbody><tr><td class="ind" indent="0"><img src="s.gif" height="1" width="0"></td><td valign="top" class="votelinks"><center><a id="up_44826563" href="vote?id=44826563&amp;how=up&amp;goto=item%3Fid%3D44826997"><div class="votearrow" title="upvote"></div></a></center></td><td class="default"><div style="margin-top:2px; margin-bottom:-10px;"><span class="comhead"><a href="user?id=atonse" class="hnuser">atonse</a> <span class="age" title="2025-08-07T16:25:03 1754583903"><a href="item?id=44826563">2 hours ago</a></span> <span id="unv_44826563"></span><span class="navs">| <a href="#44828079" class="clicky" aria-hidden="true">prev</a> | <a href="#44829098" class="clicky" aria-hidden="true">next</a> <a class="togg clicky" id="44826563" n="13" href="javascript:void(0)">[–]</a><span class="onstory"></span></span></span></div><br><div class="comment"><div class="commtext c00">For day to day coding, I've found Anthropic to be killing it with Sonnet 3.7 and now Sonnet 4, and Claude Code feeling like it has even bigger advantages over when it's used in Cursor (And I can't explain why).<p>I don't even try to use the OpenAI models because it's felt like night and day.</p><p>Hopefully GPT-5 helps them catch up. Although I'm sure there are 100 people that have their own personal "hopefully GPT-5 fixes my personal issue with GPT4"</p></div><div class="reply"><p><font size="1"><u><a href="reply?id=44826563&amp;goto=item%3Fid%3D44826997%2344826563" rel="nofollow">reply</a></u></font></p></div></div></td></tr></tbody></table>

<table border="0"><tbody><tr><td class="ind" indent="1"><img src="s.gif" height="1" width="40"></td><td valign="top" class="votelinks"><center><a id="up_44826706" href="vote?id=44826706&amp;how=up&amp;goto=item%3Fid%3D44826997"><div class="votearrow" title="upvote"></div></a></center></td><td class="default"><div style="margin-top:2px; margin-bottom:-10px;"><span class="comhead"><a href="user?id=IdealeZahlen" class="hnuser">IdealeZahlen</a> <span class="age" title="2025-08-07T16:35:44 1754584544"><a href="item?id=44826706">2 hours ago</a></span> <span id="unv_44826706"></span><span class="navs">| <a href="#44826563" class="clicky" aria-hidden="true">parent</a> | <a href="#44826695" class="clicky" aria-hidden="true">next</a> <a class="togg clicky" id="44826706" n="7" href="javascript:void(0)">[–]</a><span class="onstory"></span></span></span></div><br><div class="comment"><div class="commtext c00">Whatever the benchmarks might say, there's something about Claude that seems to deliver consistently (although not always perfect) quite reliable outputs across various coding tasks. I wonder what that 'secret sauce' might be and whether GPT-5 has figured it out too.</div><div class="reply"><p><font size="1"><u><a href="reply?id=44826706&amp;goto=item%3Fid%3D44826997%2344826706" rel="nofollow">reply</a></u></font></p></div></div></td></tr></tbody></table>

<table border="0"><tbody><tr><td class="ind" indent="2"><img src="s.gif" height="1" width="80"></td><td valign="top" class="votelinks"><center><a id="up_44826881" href="vote?id=44826881&amp;how=up&amp;goto=item%3Fid%3D44826997"><div class="votearrow" title="upvote"></div></a></center></td><td class="default"><div style="margin-top:2px; margin-bottom:-10px;"><span class="comhead"><a href="user?id=atonse" class="hnuser">atonse</a> <span class="age" title="2025-08-07T16:50:31 1754585431"><a href="item?id=44826881">2 hours ago</a></span> <span id="unv_44826881"></span><span class="navs">| <a href="#44826563" class="clicky" aria-hidden="true">root</a> | <a href="#44826706" class="clicky" aria-hidden="true">parent</a> | <a href="#44827093" class="clicky" aria-hidden="true">next</a> <a class="togg clicky" id="44826881" n="1" href="javascript:void(0)">[–]</a><span class="onstory"></span></span></span></div><br><div class="comment"><div class="commtext c00">That's been my experience too. Even though Gemini also does seem to do the fancy one-shot demo code well, in day to day coding, Claude seems to do a much better job of just understanding how programming actually works, what to do, what not to do, etc.</div><div class="reply"><p><font size="1"><u><a href="reply?id=44826881&amp;goto=item%3Fid%3D44826997%2344826881" rel="nofollow">reply</a></u></font></p></div></div></td></tr></tbody></table>

<table border="0"><tbody><tr><td class="ind" indent="2"><img src="s.gif" height="1" width="80"></td><td valign="top" class="votelinks"><center><a id="up_44827093" href="vote?id=44827093&amp;how=up&amp;goto=item%3Fid%3D44826997"><div class="votearrow" title="upvote"></div></a></center></td><td class="default"><div style="margin-top:2px; margin-bottom:-10px;"><span class="comhead"><a href="user?id=weego" class="hnuser">weego</a> <span class="age" title="2025-08-07T17:06:15 1754586375"><a href="item?id=44827093">2 hours ago</a></span> <span id="unv_44827093"></span><span class="navs">| <a href="#44826563" class="clicky" aria-hidden="true">root</a> | <a href="#44826706" class="clicky" aria-hidden="true">parent</a> | <a href="#44826881" class="clicky" aria-hidden="true">prev</a> | <a href="#44828402" class="clicky" aria-hidden="true">next</a> <a class="togg clicky" id="44827093" n="3" href="javascript:void(0)">[–]</a><span class="onstory"></span></span></span></div><br><div class="comment"><div class="commtext c00">Agreed, I always give my one pager product briefs to AI to break down into phases and tasks, and then progress trackers. I explicitly prompt for verbose phases, tasks and test plans.<p>Yesterday without much promoting Claude 4.1 gave me 10 phases, each with 5-12 tasks that could genuinely be used to kanban out a product step by step.</p><p>Claude 3.7 sonnet was effectively the same with fewer granular suggestions for programming strategies.</p><p>Gemini 2.5 gave me a one pager back with some trivial bullet points in 3 phases, no tasks at all.</p><p>o3 did the same as as Gemini, just less coherent.</p><p>Claude just has whatever the thing is for now</p></div><div class="reply"><p><font size="1"><u><a href="reply?id=44827093&amp;goto=item%3Fid%3D44826997%2344827093" rel="nofollow">reply</a></u></font></p></div></div></td></tr></tbody></table>

<table border="0"><tbody><tr><td class="ind" indent="3"><img src="s.gif" height="1" width="120"></td><td valign="top" class="votelinks"><center><a id="up_44827976" href="vote?id=44827976&amp;how=up&amp;goto=item%3Fid%3D44826997"><div class="votearrow" title="upvote"></div></a></center></td><td class="default"><div style="margin-top:2px; margin-bottom:-10px;"><span class="comhead"><a href="user?id=swyx" class="hnuser">swyx</a> <span class="age" title="2025-08-07T17:56:44 1754589404"><a href="item?id=44827976">1 hour ago</a></span> <span id="unv_44827976"></span><span class="navs">| <a href="#44827005" class="clicky" aria-hidden="true">root</a> | <a href="#44827566" class="clicky" aria-hidden="true">parent</a> | <a href="#44827248" class="clicky" aria-hidden="true">next</a> <a class="togg clicky" id="44827976" n="1" href="javascript:void(0)">[–]</a><span class="onstory"></span></span></span></div><br><div class="comment"><div class="commtext c5A">they had a bad graph on stream which they have since fixed. wouldnt get too upset about a simple error</div><div class="reply"><p><font size="1"><u><a href="reply?id=44827976&amp;goto=item%3Fid%3D44826997%2344827976" rel="nofollow">reply</a></u></font></p></div></div></td></tr></tbody></table>

<table border="0"><tbody><tr><td class="ind" indent="1"><img src="s.gif" height="1" width="40"></td><td valign="top" class="votelinks"><center><a id="up_44827248" href="vote?id=44827248&amp;how=up&amp;goto=item%3Fid%3D44826997"><div class="votearrow" title="upvote"></div></a></center></td><td class="default"><div style="margin-top:2px; margin-bottom:-10px;"><span class="comhead"><a href="user?id=swyx" class="hnuser">swyx</a> <span class="age" title="2025-08-07T17:14:07 1754586847"><a href="item?id=44827248">2 hours ago</a></span> <span id="unv_44827248"></span><span class="navs">| <a href="#44827005" class="clicky" aria-hidden="true">parent</a> | <a href="#44827530" class="clicky" aria-hidden="true">prev</a> | <a href="#44827599" class="clicky" aria-hidden="true">next</a> <a class="togg clicky" id="44827248" n="17" href="javascript:void(0)">[–]</a><span class="onstory"></span></span></span></div><br><div class="comment"><div class="commtext c00">our hands on review: <a href="https://www.latent.space/p/gpt-5-review" rel="nofollow">https://www.latent.space/p/gpt-5-review</a><p>basically in my testing really felt that gpt5 was "using tools to think" rather than just "using tools". it gets very powerful when coding long horizon tasks (a separate post i'm publishing later).</p><p>to give one substantive example, in my developer beta (they will release the video in a bit) i put it to a task that claude code had been stuck on for the last week - same prompts - and it just added logging to instrument some of the failures that we were seeing and - from the logs that it added and asked me to rerun - figured out the solve.</p></div><div class="reply"><p><font size="1"><u><a href="reply?id=44827248&amp;goto=item%3Fid%3D44826997%2344827248" rel="nofollow">reply</a></u></font></p></div></div></td></tr></tbody></table>

They're too biased to not lie<p>It's hard to make a man understand something standing between them and their salary</p></div><div class="reply"><p><font size="1"><u><a href="reply?id=44827463&amp;goto=item%3Fid%3D44826997%2344827463" rel="nofollow">reply</a></u></font></p></div></div></td></tr></tbody></table>

<table border="0"><tbody><tr><td class="ind" indent="4"><img src="s.gif" height="1" width="160"></td><td valign="top" class="votelinks"><center><a id="up_44827675" href="vote?id=44827675&amp;how=up&amp;goto=item%3Fid%3D44826997"><div class="votearrow" title="upvote"></div></a></center></td><td class="default"><div style="margin-top:2px; margin-bottom:-10px;"><span class="comhead"><a href="user?id=barrell" class="hnuser">barrell</a> <span class="age" title="2025-08-07T17:40:17 1754588417"><a href="item?id=44827675">1 hour ago</a></span> <span id="unv_44827675"></span><span class="navs">| <a href="#44827005" class="clicky" aria-hidden="true">root</a> | <a href="#44827463" class="clicky" aria-hidden="true">parent</a> | <a href="#44827466" class="clicky" aria-hidden="true">next</a> <a class="togg clicky" id="44827675" n="1" href="javascript:void(0)">[–]</a><span class="onstory"></span></span></span></div><br><div class="comment"><div class="commtext c00">I don’t think that’s a valid excuse. Yes marketing speak has always existed, but it’s not like companies have always been completely unreliable.<p>I found it strange that, despite my excitement for such an event being roughly equivalent to WWDC these days, I had 0 desire to watch the live stream for exactly this reason: it’s not like they’re going to give anything to us straight.</p><p>Even this years WWDC I at least skipped through video afterwards. Before I used to have watch parties. Yes they’re overly positive and paint everything in a good light, but they never felt… idk whatever the vibe is I get from these (applicable to OpenAI, Grok, Meta, etc)</p><p>It’s been just a few years of a revolutionary technology and already the livestreams are less appealing than the biggest corporations yearly events. Personally I find that sad</p></div><div class="reply"><p><font size="1"><u><a href="reply?id=44827675&amp;goto=item%3Fid%3D44826997%2344827675" rel="nofollow">reply</a></u></font></p></div></div></td></tr></tbody></table>

<table border="0"><tbody><tr><td class="ind" indent="3"><img src="s.gif" height="1" width="120"></td><td valign="top" class="votelinks"><center><a id="up_44827466" href="vote?id=44827466&amp;how=up&amp;goto=item%3Fid%3D44826997"><div class="votearrow" title="upvote"></div></a></center></td><td class="default"><div style="margin-top:2px; margin-bottom:-10px;"><span class="comhead"><a href="user?id=swyx" class="hnuser">swyx</a> <span class="age" title="2025-08-07T17:26:53 1754587613"><a href="item?id=44827466">1 hour ago</a></span> <span id="unv_44827466"></span><span class="navs">| <a href="#44827005" class="clicky" aria-hidden="true">root</a> | <a href="#44827364" class="clicky" aria-hidden="true">parent</a> | <a href="#44827463" class="clicky" aria-hidden="true">prev</a> | <a href="#44828420" class="clicky" aria-hidden="true">next</a> <a class="togg clicky" id="44827466" n="2" href="javascript:void(0)">[–]</a><span class="onstory"></span></span></span></div><br><div class="comment"><div class="commtext c00">better than 4o but worse than 4.5 is internally consistent. and ofc writing is extremely multidimensional.</div><div class="reply"><p><font size="1"><u><a href="reply?id=44827466&amp;goto=item%3Fid%3D44826997%2344827466" rel="nofollow">reply</a></u></font></p></div></div></td></tr></tbody></table>

<table border="0"><tbody><tr><td class="ind" indent="4"><img src="s.gif" height="1" width="160"></td><td valign="top" class="votelinks"><center><a id="up_44827763" href="vote?id=44827763&amp;how=up&amp;goto=item%3Fid%3D44826997"><div class="votearrow" title="upvote"></div></a></center></td><td class="default"><div style="margin-top:2px; margin-bottom:-10px;"><span class="comhead"><a href="user?id=WhitneyLand" class="hnuser">WhitneyLand</a> <span class="age" title="2025-08-07T17:44:36 1754588676"><a href="item?id=44827763">1 hour ago</a></span> <span id="unv_44827763"></span><span class="navs">| <a href="#44827005" class="clicky" aria-hidden="true">root</a> | <a href="#44827466" class="clicky" aria-hidden="true">parent</a> | <a href="#44828420" class="clicky" aria-hidden="true">next</a> <a class="togg clicky" id="44827763" n="1" href="javascript:void(0)">[–]</a><span class="onstory"></span></span></span></div><br><div class="comment"><div class="commtext c00">But that’s not what the review says:<p>“It’s actually worse at writing than GPT-4.5, and I think even 4o”</p><p>So the review is not consistent with the PR, hence the commenter expressing preference for outside sources.</p></div><div class="reply"><p><font size="1"><u><a href="reply?id=44827763&amp;goto=item%3Fid%3D44826997%2344827763" rel="nofollow">reply</a></u></font></p></div></div></td></tr></tbody></table>

<table border="0"><tbody><tr><td class="ind" indent="2"><img src="s.gif" height="1" width="80"></td><td valign="top" class="votelinks"><center><a id="up_44828420" href="vote?id=44828420&amp;how=up&amp;goto=item%3Fid%3D44826997"><div class="votearrow" title="upvote"></div></a></center></td><td class="default"><div style="margin-top:2px; margin-bottom:-10px;"><span class="comhead"><a href="user?id=billmalarky" class="hnuser">billmalarky</a> <span class="age" title="2025-08-07T18:24:13 1754591053"><a href="item?id=44828420">54 minutes ago</a></span> <span id="unv_44828420"></span><span class="navs">| <a href="#44827005" class="clicky" aria-hidden="true">root</a> | <a href="#44827248" class="clicky" aria-hidden="true">parent</a> | <a href="#44827364" class="clicky" aria-hidden="true">prev</a> | <a href="#44827430" class="clicky" aria-hidden="true">next</a> <a class="togg clicky" id="44828420" n="1" href="javascript:void(0)">[–]</a><span class="onstory"></span></span></span></div><br><div class="comment"><div class="commtext c00">Hi Swyx I always appreciate your insights, something you wrote really resonated with a personal theory I've been developing:<p>&gt;"While I never use AI for personal writing (because I have a strong belief in writing to think)"</p><p>The optimal AI productivity process is starting to look like:</p><p>AI Generates &gt; Human Validates &gt; Loop</p><p>Yet cognitive generation is how humans learn and develop cognitive strength, as well as how they maintain such strength.</p><p>Similar to how physical activity is how muscles/bone density/etc grow, and how body tissues maintain.</p><p>Physical technology freed us from hard physical labor that kept our bodies in shape -- at a cost of physical atrophy.</p><p>AI seems to have a similar effect for our minds. AI will accelerate our cognitive productivity, and allow for cognitive convenience -- at a cost of cognitive atrophy.</p><p>At present we must be intentional about building/maintaining physical strength (dedicated strength training, cardio, etc).</p><p>Soon we will need to be intentional about building/maintaining cognitive strength.</p><p>I suspect the workday/week of the future will be split on AI-on-a-leash work for optimal productivity, with carve-outs for dedicated AI-enhanced-learning solely for building/maintaining cognitive health (where productivity is not the goal, building/maintaining cognition is). Similar to how we carve out time for working out.</p><p>What are your thoughts on this? Based on what you wrote above, it seems you have similar feelings?</p><p>Is there a name for this theory?</p><p>If not can you coin one? You're great at that :)</p></div><div class="reply"><p><font size="1"><u><a href="reply?id=44828420&amp;goto=item%3Fid%3D44826997%2344828420" rel="nofollow">reply</a></u></font></p></div></div></td></tr></tbody></table>

<table border="0"><tbody><tr><td class="ind" indent="2"><img src="s.gif" height="1" width="80"></td><td valign="top" class="votelinks"><center><a id="up_44827430" href="vote?id=44827430&amp;how=up&amp;goto=item%3Fid%3D44826997"><div class="votearrow" title="upvote"></div></a></center></td><td class="default"><div style="margin-top:2px; margin-bottom:-10px;"><span class="comhead"><a href="user?id=thierrydamiba" class="hnuser">thierrydamiba</a> <span class="age" title="2025-08-07T17:24:34 1754587474"><a href="item?id=44827430">1 hour ago</a></span> <span id="unv_44827430"></span><span class="navs">| <a href="#44827005" class="clicky" aria-hidden="true">root</a> | <a href="#44827248" class="clicky" aria-hidden="true">parent</a> | <a href="#44828420" class="clicky" aria-hidden="true">prev</a> | <a href="#44827502" class="clicky" aria-hidden="true">next</a> <a class="togg clicky" id="44827430" n="2" href="javascript:void(0)">[–]</a><span class="onstory"></span></span></span></div><br><div class="comment"><div class="commtext c00">Great writeup. I particularly like the idea of splitting your tools into the four buckets.<p>1)Internal Retrieval</p><p>2)Web Search</p><p>3)Code Interpreter</p><p>4)Actions</p><p>How did you come up with this idea?</p></div><div class="reply"><p><font size="1"><u><a href="reply?id=44827430&amp;goto=item%3Fid%3D44826997%2344827430" rel="nofollow">reply</a></u></font></p></div></div></td></tr></tbody></table>

<table border="0"><tbody><tr><td class="ind" indent="3"><img src="s.gif" height="1" width="120"></td><td valign="top" class="votelinks"><center><a id="up_44827458" href="vote?id=44827458&amp;how=up&amp;goto=item%3Fid%3D44826997"><div class="votearrow" title="upvote"></div></a></center></td><td class="default"><div style="margin-top:2px; margin-bottom:-10px;"><span class="comhead"><a href="user?id=swyx" class="hnuser">swyx</a> <span class="age" title="2025-08-07T17:26:34 1754587594"><a href="item?id=44827458">1 hour ago</a></span> <span id="unv_44827458"></span><span class="navs">| <a href="#44827005" class="clicky" aria-hidden="true">root</a> | <a href="#44827430" class="clicky" aria-hidden="true">parent</a> | <a href="#44827502" class="clicky" aria-hidden="true">next</a> <a class="togg clicky" id="44827458" n="1" href="javascript:void(0)">[–]</a><span class="onstory"></span></span></span></div><br><div class="comment"><div class="commtext c00">ive been pushing the idea of "the Big 3" tools (<a href="https://news.smol.ai/issues/25-05-27-mistral-agents" rel="nofollow">https://news.smol.ai/issues/25-05-27-mistral-agents</a> and <a href="https://www.latent.space/p/agent" rel="nofollow">https://www.latent.space/p/agent</a>) and Ben added a 4th</div><div class="reply"><p><font size="1"><u><a href="reply?id=44827458&amp;goto=item%3Fid%3D44826997%2344827458" rel="nofollow">reply</a></u></font></p></div></div></td></tr></tbody></table>

<table border="0"><tbody><tr><td class="ind" indent="2"><img src="s.gif" height="1" width="80"></td><td valign="top" class="votelinks"><center><a id="up_44827502" href="vote?id=44827502&amp;how=up&amp;goto=item%3Fid%3D44826997"><div class="votearrow" title="upvote"></div></a></center></td><td class="default"><div style="margin-top:2px; margin-bottom:-10px;"><span class="comhead"><a href="user?id=lyxell" class="hnuser">lyxell</a> <span class="age" title="2025-08-07T17:28:27 1754587707"><a href="item?id=44827502">1 hour ago</a></span> <span id="unv_44827502"></span><span class="navs">| <a href="#44827005" class="clicky" aria-hidden="true">root</a> | <a href="#44827248" class="clicky" aria-hidden="true">parent</a> | <a href="#44827430" class="clicky" aria-hidden="true">prev</a> | <a href="#44827599" class="clicky" aria-hidden="true">next</a> <a class="togg clicky" id="44827502" n="8" href="javascript:void(0)">[–]</a><span class="onstory"></span></span></span></div><br><div class="comment"><div class="commtext c00">”I think GPT-5 is the closest to AGI we’ve ever been”<p>Sorry, but this sounds like overly sensational marketing speak and just leaves a bad taste in the mouth for me.</p></div><div class="reply"><p><font size="1"><u><a href="reply?id=44827502&amp;goto=item%3Fid%3D44826997%2344827502" rel="nofollow">reply</a></u></font></p></div></div></td></tr></tbody></table>

<table border="0"><tbody><tr><td class="ind" indent="3"><img src="s.gif" height="1" width="120"></td><td valign="top" class="votelinks"><center><a id="up_44827541" href="vote?id=44827541&amp;how=up&amp;goto=item%3Fid%3D44826997"><div class="votearrow" title="upvote"></div></a></center></td><td class="default"><div style="margin-top:2px; margin-bottom:-10px;"><span class="comhead"><a href="user?id=Aurornis" class="hnuser">Aurornis</a> <span class="age" title="2025-08-07T17:30:53 1754587853"><a href="item?id=44827541">1 hour ago</a></span> <span id="unv_44827541"></span><span class="navs">| <a href="#44827005" class="clicky" aria-hidden="true">root</a> | <a href="#44827502" class="clicky" aria-hidden="true">parent</a> | <a href="#44827586" class="clicky" aria-hidden="true">next</a> <a class="togg clicky" id="44827541" n="4" href="javascript:void(0)">[–]</a><span class="onstory"></span></span></span></div><br><div class="comment"><div class="commtext c00">I found a Hacker News thread via Google a few days ago. One of the top comments was from someone describing their RAG architecture and a certain technique (my search term). The comment boasted that their system was so good it that their team thought they created something close to AGI.<p>Then I noticed the date on the comment: 2023.</p><p>Technically, every advancement in the space is “the closest to AGI that we’ve ever been”. It’s technically correct, since we’re not moving backward. It’s just not a very meaningful statement.</p></div><div class="reply"><p><font size="1"><u><a href="reply?id=44827541&amp;goto=item%3Fid%3D44826997%2344827541" rel="nofollow">reply</a></u></font></p></div></div></td></tr></tbody></table>

<table border="0"><tbody><tr><td class="ind" indent="1"><img src="s.gif" height="1" width="40"></td><td valign="top" class="votelinks"><center><a id="up_44827544" href="vote?id=44827544&amp;how=up&amp;goto=item%3Fid%3D44826997"><div class="votearrow" title="upvote"></div></a></center></td><td class="default"><div style="margin-top:2px; margin-bottom:-10px;"><span class="comhead"><a href="user?id=motoxpro" class="hnuser">motoxpro</a> <span class="age" title="2025-08-07T17:31:01 1754587861"><a href="item?id=44827544">1 hour ago</a></span> <span id="unv_44827544"></span><span class="navs">| <a href="#44827250" class="clicky" aria-hidden="true">parent</a> | <a href="#44827387" class="clicky" aria-hidden="true">next</a> <a class="togg clicky" id="44827544" n="17" href="javascript:void(0)">[–]</a><span class="onstory"></span></span></span></div><br><div class="comment"><div class="commtext c00">They are researchers, not professional presenters. I promise you if I told you to do a live demo, on stage, for 20 minutes, going back and forth between scripted and unscripted content, to an audience of at least 50 million people, that unless you do this a lot, you would do the same or worse. I know this because this is what I do for a living. I have seen 1000s of "normal" people be extremely awkward on stage. Much more so than this.<p>It's super unfortunate that, becasue we live in the social media/youtube era, that everyone is expected to be this perfect person on camera, because why wouldn't they be? That's all they see.</p><p>I am glad that they use normal people who act like themselves rather than them hiring actors or taking researchers away from what they love to do and tell them they need to become professional in-front-of-camera people because "we have the gpt-5 launch" That would be a nightmare.</p><p>It's a group of scientists sharings their work with the world, but people just want "better marketing" :\</p></div><div class="reply"><p><font size="1"><u><a href="reply?id=44827544&amp;goto=item%3Fid%3D44826997%2344827544" rel="nofollow">reply</a></u></font></p></div></div></td></tr></tbody></table>

<table border="0"><tbody><tr><td class="ind" indent="2"><img src="s.gif" height="1" width="80"></td><td valign="top" class="votelinks"><center><a id="up_44827740" href="vote?id=44827740&amp;how=up&amp;goto=item%3Fid%3D44826997"><div class="votearrow" title="upvote"></div></a></center></td><td class="default"><div style="margin-top:2px; margin-bottom:-10px;"><span class="comhead"><a href="user?id=retsibsi" class="hnuser">retsibsi</a> <span class="age" title="2025-08-07T17:43:16 1754588596"><a href="item?id=44827740">1 hour ago</a></span> <span id="unv_44827740"></span><span class="navs">| <a href="#44827250" class="clicky" aria-hidden="true">root</a> | <a href="#44827544" class="clicky" aria-hidden="true">parent</a> | <a href="#44828013" class="clicky" aria-hidden="true">next</a> <a class="togg clicky" id="44827740" n="5" href="javascript:void(0)">[–]</a><span class="onstory"></span></span></span></div><br><div class="comment"><div class="commtext c00">I think they're copping this criticism because it's neither one thing nor the other. If it was really just a group of scientists being themselves, some of us would appreciate that. And if it was inauthentic but performed by great actors, most people wouldn't notice or care about the fakeness. This is somewhere in the middle, so it feels very unnatural and a bit weird.</div><div class="reply"><p><font size="1"><u><a href="reply?id=44827740&amp;goto=item%3Fid%3D44826997%2344827740" rel="nofollow">reply</a></u></font></p></div></div></td></tr></tbody></table>

<table border="0"><tbody><tr><td class="ind" indent="3"><img src="s.gif" height="1" width="120"></td><td valign="top" class="votelinks"><center><a id="up_44827833" href="vote?id=44827833&amp;how=up&amp;goto=item%3Fid%3D44826997"><div class="votearrow" title="upvote"></div></a></center></td><td class="default"><div style="margin-top:2px; margin-bottom:-10px;"><span class="comhead"><a href="user?id=motoxpro" class="hnuser">motoxpro</a> <span class="age" title="2025-08-07T17:48:16 1754588896"><a href="item?id=44827833">1 hour ago</a></span> <span id="unv_44827833"></span><span class="navs">| <a href="#44827250" class="clicky" aria-hidden="true">root</a> | <a href="#44827740" class="clicky" aria-hidden="true">parent</a> | <a href="#44828195" class="clicky" aria-hidden="true">next</a> <a class="togg clicky" id="44827833" n="3" href="javascript:void(0)">[–]</a><span class="onstory"></span></span></span></div><br><div class="comment"><div class="commtext c00">You're describing low skilled presenters. That is what it looks like when you put someone up in front of a camera and tell them to communicate a lot of information. You're not thinking about "being yourself," you're thinking about how to not forget your lines, not mess up, not think about the different outcomes of the prompt that you might have to deal with, etc.<p>This was my point. "Being yourself" on camera is hard. This comes across, apparently shockingly, as being devoid of emotion and/or robotic</p></div><div class="reply"><p><font size="1"><u><a href="reply?id=44827833&amp;goto=item%3Fid%3D44826997%2344827833" rel="nofollow">reply</a></u></font></p></div></div></td></tr></tbody></table>

<table border="0"><tbody><tr><td class="ind" indent="4"><img src="s.gif" height="1" width="160"></td><td valign="top" class="votelinks"><center><a id="up_44827965" href="vote?id=44827965&amp;how=up&amp;goto=item%3Fid%3D44826997"><div class="votearrow" title="upvote"></div></a></center></td><td class="default"><div style="margin-top:2px; margin-bottom:-10px;"><span class="comhead"><a href="user?id=retsibsi" class="hnuser">retsibsi</a> <span class="age" title="2025-08-07T17:56:07 1754589367"><a href="item?id=44827965">1 hour ago</a></span> <span id="unv_44827965"></span><span class="navs">| <a href="#44827250" class="clicky" aria-hidden="true">root</a> | <a href="#44827833" class="clicky" aria-hidden="true">parent</a> | <a href="#44828195" class="clicky" aria-hidden="true">next</a> <a class="togg clicky" id="44827965" n="2" href="javascript:void(0)">[–]</a><span class="onstory"></span></span></span></div><br><div class="comment"><div class="commtext c00">Yeah, but I disagree with you a bit. Or if they unashamedly leant into the scriptedness and didn't try to simulate normal human interaction, they would be criticised for being "wooden" or whatever, but it wouldn't have this slightly creepy vibe.</div><div class="reply"><p><font size="1"><u><a href="reply?id=44827965&amp;goto=item%3Fid%3D44826997%2344827965" rel="nofollow">reply</a></u></font></p></div></div></td></tr></tbody></table>

<table border="0"><tbody><tr><td class="ind" indent="5"><img src="s.gif" height="1" width="200"></td><td valign="top" class="votelinks"><center><a id="up_44828060" href="vote?id=44828060&amp;how=up&amp;goto=item%3Fid%3D44826997"><div class="votearrow" title="upvote"></div></a></center></td><td class="default"><div style="margin-top:2px; margin-bottom:-10px;"><span class="comhead"><a href="user?id=motoxpro" class="hnuser">motoxpro</a> <span class="age" title="2025-08-07T18:01:11 1754589671"><a href="item?id=44828060">1 hour ago</a></span> <span id="unv_44828060"></span><span class="navs">| <a href="#44827250" class="clicky" aria-hidden="true">root</a> | <a href="#44827965" class="clicky" aria-hidden="true">parent</a> | <a href="#44828195" class="clicky" aria-hidden="true">next</a> <a class="togg clicky" id="44828060" n="1" href="javascript:void(0)">[–]</a><span class="onstory"></span></span></span></div><br><div class="comment"><div class="commtext c00">I get you.<p>I think for me, just knowing what is probably on the teleprompter, and what is not, I am willing to bet a lot of the "wooden" vibe you are getting is actually NOT scripted.</p><p>There is no way for people to remember that 20 minutes of dialog, so when they are not looking at the camera, that is unscripted, and viceversa.</p></div><div class="reply"><p><font size="1"><u><a href="reply?id=44828060&amp;goto=item%3Fid%3D44826997%2344828060" rel="nofollow">reply</a></u></font></p></div></div></td></tr></tbody></table>
